I know it's a little late, but here is my Dad, a charter member of the 30th Engineer Bn (Topo) here on FT Belvoir ca. 1941-1942.  He served a total of 20 years (Jan 1940 - Jan 1960) retiring as a CW3.  He then undertook another 20 years of Civil Service working for Army Map Service, which became Defense Mapping Agency (now NGA) where he worked on the Lunar Orbiter mapping of the moon for the Apollo missions and the Mariner mapping of Mars.

To say he was an inspiration to me would be an understatement.

For instance, opening Walker and Beulah would be helpful. Obviously the personnel who would have been working at the closed gate can work there. We think 1st Sgt. Jackson agrees, too.

Doesn't help that when soldiers try to receive help all they get is backlash from leadership about "too many appointments" or "you're a NCO, you need to learn how to handle these things". We're still losing too many soldiers daily and the Army chain of command still makes behavioral health taboo or punishable. We all gasp at the idea of "punishment" for those who need help, but I've seen people get an article 15 for attempted suicide, rank reduction boards, and overall loss of support where it destroys an NCOs career and home life. Now, the Army is losing good soldiers because they can't balance their health, career, and family. A broken life is a good title for this article. I feel many soldiers and their families can relate to being "broken" by and within the military life.

I got one of these calls last week. The voicemail actually sounded pretty official. The recording said:

"The reason of this call is to inform you that the IRS is filing lawsuit against you. To get more information about this case file, please call immediately, on our department line, 213-713-0657..." then they repeat the call back number one more time and say, "thank you".

Thankfully a quick Google search showed that the numbers (different number called me than what they left as a call back number) had been reported, many times, as a scam call.

If you're in doubt. Always try searching their numbers first. More often than not, you'll find reports of it being scam calls!
You should also be aware of the IRS's abuse.

Yes for us and our pets!! Since it touched my life so horribly - Im on a soapbox about flea/tick prevention for our pets. Even if they only go out quickly to use the bathroom.... get the medicine and use it. There are great new products on the market that are oral and seem to be more effective. My dog contracted Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever here(low positive) - (even though she has been on flea/tick treatment since a puppy) and she really only goes out to potty. The disease caused secondary glaucoma and she had to have her eye removed. Dont think it cant happen. I never thought it could.

Are there any current plans to secure off-post housing areas? In today?s day and age, there are not many military locations (if any) that are left unsecured. Fort Bragg has a similar off-post housing area that is secured - and even has a Fire Station and MP patrol unit! Many agree that this is a disservice to the residents and should be corrected immediately! We understand that there is an increased cost associated with improved security, but exactly what price can be applied to the safety and security of our servicemembers, their families, and their belongings? Are they not important enough? Would this issue be fixed if higher ranking personnel were assigned military housing off-post? We also understand that living in military housing is an option, and a privilege, but many of our junior enlisted servicemembers have limited options in this high cost of living area - and have elected to live in military housing for safety, security, and community. Numerous petitions have been previously conducted to make this a reality, but other than random security checks, not much has been done. We respectfully request that this issue be raised to DES and the Garrison Commander. Safety should be a top priority for all servicemembers and their families, please right this wrong immediately!

EXTREMELY risky walking this A.M. -- I nearly fell twice -- so please be careful, slow down and take your time. I know there are several entities making delayed opening calls for Ft. Belvoir, however -- any agency opening on time this morning made a very, VERY bad call.

Here are some useful tips - handy if flooding happens later today in the area: 
Move immediately to higher ground. 
Do not wait for instructions to move.
Always stay away from floodwaters. 
? Even six inches of swiftly moving water can knock someone off their feet. 
? Be aware of streams, drainage channels and other areas known to flood suddenly. 
? Keep your children inside and away from streams and creeks.  Stay away from downed power lines to avoid the risk of electric shock or electrocution 
Do not drive on flooded roads ? "turn around, don?t drown." 
? The depth, current and condition of the road are all unknowns and can be deadly. 
? If your vehicle stalls on a flooded road and water is rising, get out of the car, call 9-1-1 and move to higher ground. 
? Approximately two feet of swift water can move or float most vehicles, including SUV?s and pickup trucks. 
? Be especially cautious during periods of limited visibility or nighttime when it is extremely difficult to see and judge conditions -- state law requires headlights when wipers are on.

Fairfax County Public Schools posted this eariler today: 
While road conditions are improving, they vary greatly across the County, with some roads not yet clear. In order to open safely as soon as road conditions permit, FCPS crews are working around-the-clock to clear access to schools and offices. FCPS will continue to monitor the situation daily and another update will be provided tomorrow afternoon. Changes to the end of the semester dates are under evaluation and any changes will be communicated when possible.
All Fairfax County public schools and offices will be closed Wednesday, January 27, 2016 (Condition 1).
The following activities in schools and on school grounds are canceled:
* extracurricular activities
* interscholastic contests
* team practices
* field trips
* middle school after-school programs
* professional learning and training courses
* adult and community education classes
* recreation programs and community use by outside groups not affiliated with FCPS.
School age child care (SACC) centers are closed.

Just in case it's not known, housing is separate from the base. The base is not responsible for the snow removal in housing. The Villages is responsible, Fort Belvoir, the base, has its own contracts for snow removal which are separate from housing. Every base I have been on has been this way. So complaining on this sight does nothing. If one has a complaint about the snow removal in housing then complain to the Villages. This sight is simply spreading the word of The Villages.

It's about da*n time this was addressed!  I have seen several close calls with drivers turning left into the Gas Station from Southbound Gunston only to have the cars behind them slam on their brakes when they realize that the driver ahead of them was making an ILLEGAL left turn.  There is no turn lane therefore no left turn allowed.

Maybe someone could request the lights at John kingman and gunston be timed a little better. The long wait going straight on John kingman makes sense (though stinks) during morning rush, lunch, and evening rush. But man it is sooooooo long in evening hours when heading to the px or something. It's just bad. :(

And, there are many other areas on post that could use some traffic re-engineering other than here.  For example - all of the lights on Gunston that change to red when a vehicle is making a right turn onto Gunston.  The light changes well after the car is on their way down the road.  how about fixing those sensors?

Is there any reason for this "no left turn" area?  I have not seen a number of accidents there and cars can turn left coming out of the shoppette across traffic in that location.  Anyone leaving the PX across from the gas station has no way to get into the gas station except to turn at that spot.
There's also a "no left turn" as you exit the North Post Shopette on Gorgas.  It's enforced about as much, and even the blocking cones were removed.
People are STILL turning left there. Regardless of the signs, billboards, flashing lights, you name it, they still do it.
Smallest sign ever.

Not sure why people with kids at JB CDC had to hear about this on the news before CYS. Even if our kids weren't in the room with the infected child, we should have all been immediately notified. Teachera move around the building too much to not tell everyone. You lose nothing by over communicating except the respect of the parents.
Out of curiosity, what is the "appropriate action?" My child attends JBCDC and I still have NOT been contacted by Fort Belvoir.

The second dose is not due until Kindergarten so all children at JB are at risk unless they received their second shot early. (Can receive between 4-6 years old).  The real issue is JB never informed parents until already on news and facebook.  Even then they placed handouts near the checkout desk; no signs, no discussions, nothing.  I asked which age group the child was from since they combine classes and switch teachers often.  They stated they could not disclose that for me to really evaluate my child's risk.  They said they only called those they identified as high risk; even though the entire building was listed as high risk by Fairfax County. I find their lack of communication and very delayed response to be anything but "appropriate action."

The most pressing, and unanswered, question is the infected child was immunized. The child was not old enough to receive the second MMR dose and contracted the disease. According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, the second dose is not usually given until age four. So most of the infants and children at JoAnn Blanks CDC are potential carriers, with an incubation period extending to late October.

Yea they contacted parents of children that are under 12 months and not vaccinated yet that were in attendance the day of exposure so we have to quarantine our children until the 22nd of October to prevent further spreading of it and they only informed people today because they just got confirmation of diagnosis today

I'll add that one dose of MMR vaccine is 93% effective if exposed to the disease, while two ups the effectiveness to 97%. These figures should be shared widely, and while I'm comforted by the 93% figure, you are still leaving 7% to chance for those children having only one MMR shot.

This is a great video "IF"  the belvoir circle was actually shaped like this.  The problem is that  there are 2 exits from the circle (the hospital side and the community center side) that are single lane exits.  Therefore, even if the driver in the inside lane and the driver in the right lane on Belvoir road were both wanting to exit to the community center or on the other side to the hospital there is only one lane that they both must enter.  Yes, the Belvoir road drivers should all YIELD to the driver in the circle - but being that the drivers here in the US have no idea that they are supposed to 'signal' (yes, that little blinker thing on the car) when you are exiting the circle, the Belvoir road driver has no clue if the inner circle driver is exiting or continuing on... so at times they take their chances.  This circle either needs to be single lane OR be redesigned in such a way as to force drivers to use it properly.  

In addition it would be massively helpful if the lines were kept painted. They are faded in such a way that cars drift from one lane to the other and back again as they go around the circle.

Roundabouts everywhere in Europe, I never had a problem using them there!   The intent is to keep traffic moving, so this being placed in front of a busy gate, hospital, and hotel are a great idea. I use this correctly, but have almost been side swiped by those not knowing how to properly use it. Painting lines would be a great start.

Ironically, I have followed several MP's around the traffic circle. Half of them exit to the hospital from the inside lane and the other half from the outside lane. So, when there isn't even consistency with the MP's, how can we possibly expect consistency with regular drivers? I agree the lines need to be repainted (and kept up) to better facilitate drivers who are unfamiliar with traffic circles. I also agree this video does not address the hospital exit or community center exit as they are exits where only one lane can exit, not both as addressed in the video. Another suggestion would be to include better signage at the traffic circle which would further aid drivers. I have driven around many traffic circles, and this is the most poorly designed, poorly painted, and poorly signed one I've seen.

The big problem is that because so many people ride the outside lane all the way around, many times you cannot get to the inside lane to properly utilize this circle.  At high volume times those of us who would love to properly use it cannot due to so many who do not understand the workings of traffic circles.  The fault is not really in the drivers but in the traffic engineers who think it is a great idea to place circles in areas where drivers are not trained for circles.  Single lane circles can work fine in low congestion areas like neighborhoods - they slow the rate of speed without bumps and reduce the number of unnecessary stop signs.  But highly traveled areas with multi-lane circles AND without forced traffic flow devices is simply a recipe for disaster.

Just saying building the new hotel on post right next to this roundabout is asking for problems. Why do we even have the roundabout there? Was there plans for a monument or something to go there originally that never went through?

This is good information. I have found it difficult to enter the circle from the hospital due to the large sign blocking the view of the circle. This seems like a fundamental design flaw as you can't see the traffic which will be continuing on to Belvoir road.

This is just enabling those who exit from the inner lane to the hospital. I'm surprised there have not been more accidents. I purposely wait to enter the round about from pence gate since so many drives do not use the inner lane not the outer lane to go to the hospital.

I'm sorry but the overall population on the roads today are too stupid to understand how regular traffic intersections work let alone something that requires more than 2 different actions.  Traffic circles can be great, but I just don't feel they are right for the common sense lacking driving public out there.  You have to remember, Some are already too confused about the difference between red and green.  The rest are too busy going off on their phones or other distractions to even care.
Shelly Logar, isn't this what McConnelsville has? Think we have been doing this for a while...

Painting lane lines and posting signs similar to this at each roundabout entrance would help tremendously.
This video appears to be from a Canadian driving school.  The following is the VA DOT website's instructions on roundabouts:  http://www.virginiadot.org/info/faq-roundabouts.asp
Eliminating the dual lanes would also eliminate much of the confusion.

In the 1990's I was given a coin by SMA Kidd who said "don't let me catch you without it."

A few weeks later I saw him in the Ft. Myer PX getting a haircut. Something came over me and I challenged him with his own coin.  He didn't have one.

Monday morning my 1SG told me and my squad to report in Class A's to the Hall of Heroes in the Pentagon.  SMA Kidd brought a coin for each member of my squad and brought me a caffeine free diet coke (I wasn't old enough for beer).

These are called challenge coins and used to mean something.  I received my first when I was in Special Forces in the 1970s, a 5th SFG(A) coin with my name engraved on it. I had to carry the coin at all times, if not, I'd have to buy a round of drinks for everybody present.  That is the only coin that I've received that means anything, I had to earn it.
I was first coined by then Chief of Naval Operations ADM Vern Clerk to participating in a color guard for the groundbreaking ceremony of the Navy League of the United States building.

Hooah, those who know understand the importance and sacrifice behind the presentation and the challenge.   My top to date is from then Secretary of the Army Geren.  Although a lot earned and more received, there was and is numerous others who did not receive  and still they served...honor them.

When the hot weather hits, expect everyone to be sluggish for a few days until they adjust. Get used to working in the heat gradually. Alter work routines to reduce heavy exertion in the heat of the day.
 Take frequent rest breaks when working in hot conditions. These breaks can consist of moving to a cooler area or switching to lighter work for awhile.
 Drink plenty of water and drink it often. Beverages such as coffee, cola and beer don't replenish the water in your system; they actually deplete it. Keep an emergency supply of water on hand for this and other emergencies.
 Take it easy on yourself. Avoid strenuous activities in the heat of the day, especially if you are not accustomed to them. Schedule heavy work and fitness workouts for the cooler hours.
 Take it easy on the power grid, too. Avoid unnecessary use of electricity while air conditioners are running. A power failure during a heat wave can result in more deaths.
 Hot weather is especially hard on the young, the old and those in ill health. Keep young children as
cool and comfortable as you can.
Dress lightly, in layers so that you can subtract or add clothing as the temperature
changes. Be sure to shade the skin against the sun. Remind your workers frequently to
protect themselves from sunburn by covering up with lightweight clothing and using
sunscreen.
Watch each other for signs of heat illness. Mild cases can be treated by moving the
person to a cool area and supplying water to drink. Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition
which calls for immediate medical help.

Here are the warning signals of heat illness:                                 Heat Cramps. Heat cramps affects muscles such as those in the arms, legs and abdomen ? the muscles
which have been used while working. These cramps may occur after work, when the person is resting.
Heat cramps are a signal that the body has lost too much salt through sweating.
 Heat Exhaustion. Heat exhaustion is a serious condition that needs immediate attention. It may
have any or all of these symptoms: A feeling of exhaustion, nausea, dizziness, pale and clammy skin,
quick pulse, and low blood pressure. Heat exhaustion is also a warning that the mechanism which controls heat for the body has become seriously overtaxed. Heat stroke may follow if heat exhaustion is not treated.
 Heat Stroke. Heat stroke is a serious matter and it can be fatal. It occurs when the body's heat control mechanism simply shuts down. Perspiration stops and the body temperature rises. The heart pounds and the skin becomes flushed and hot. This condition is a medical emergency and must be treated immediately.

You people are so ridiculously entitled, you must be officers' wives.  If you don't want to wait, go off post and pay for your prescriptions.  Maybe you didn't notice that there's no cash registers in evidence at the pharmacy? Out in the real world, people wait an hour for prescriptions AND they have to hand over a bunch of cash to get them.  I'll trade an hour or two for hundreds of dollars worth of free medicine (which I get after my free doctor visit) every time.

That being said, any improvement is a nice bonus.  Guess I won't look forward to pharmacy time as my reading hour anymore.
How about a disposal bin for unused prescriptions?  My doc will change a med and I'm stuck with bottles of stuff.  It would be convenient to have a drop off bin.

But what prevents you from doing the same as DEA or the Sheriffs on a regular basis? Is there some rule or a legal code that prevents the collection of unused medicines? Not enough personnel? A change in job descriptions?
It won't be an "improvement" at the main pharmacy until I can get my refills there.

You have GOT to be kidding me! 

The metal seats, shown above, do NOT have cushions!  It hurt, hurt, hurt.  Did I say it hurt?  

As for that ticket dispenser, it wasn't there yesterday. They had hand drawn numbers in a makeshift container.  

The women working in the pharmacywere shouting out the numbers, which in most cases could not be heard. 

You have GOT to bess kidding me!
An improvement would be getting your prescription in less than an hour. The wait for prescriptions at the hospital pharmacy is ridiculously and unnecessarily long!
Yesterday I suggested to my local CVS pharmacist that they use pneumatic tubes & just shoot the meds. right to my house as ordered on my prescription. She was not amused.  ;-/

ANYTHING would be an improvement! I went to the Emergency room on Tuesday Morning and it took the Pharmacy 1 hr and 42 min to fill the prescription for 21 pills!!! And last week I went in for a prescription and it took 3 hrs! TOTALLY UNACCEPTABLE!

I had a buzzer thing (like at a restaurant) that let me know my prescription was ready.  That was helpful but I felt I had to run back to the pharmacy right away, before they closed.  The snake-like lines were intimidating.
Sitting on uncomfortable seats while waiting forever for a refill is an "improvement"?

No one on or off post should have that ridiculous of a wait. I've never waited at the other 5 posts I've lived at like I wait here. PS- I'm not an officer wife nor do I feel entitled. People are aloud to have their opinions as well as you are sir.

LMBO!! really? The reason why i only use px pharmacy because i dont want to waste 1-3 hrs at hospital pharmacy. so i call in my refills you guys have three days to fill it and i always even give you guys an extra day before picking it up and yet my husband goes to pick it up today and still had to wait about hr and half or a little more. I have never had a nonstressful and frustration visit with any pharmacy inside Belvoir. And they can at least pretend to look like they are busy doing something work related and not gossiping or just, so obviously, trying to look like they are doing something. While giving us the annoyed "i hate this job and you are wasting so much of my time" look of the employees. Yes, im so sorry that i have to come over and make u do your job that u get paid to do. And to think my husband only has to risk his life everytime he gets deployed just so i can come get meds from your pharmacy.

Keep going to Rte. 1.  Finally get to the Tulley Gate turn and it's backed up too... not because they are using the arm/automated scanners but because they merge the two lanes into one right when you get up to the gate (saw a few "road rage" incidents too when people waiting in the right lane were cut off abruptly by people racing up the left lane and cutting them off).  While I appreciate the updated information, it's insane that a 10 minute commute to your office takes nearly an hour.

I'm lucky that I live on post, but I can definitely understand why there at a minimum should have been a 2 hour delay. Now I'm the only one in the office since everyone on my team that lives off post is stuck in traffic or have been involved in car accidents this morning. This is all well and good if the weakest point of post security was the gates but the weakest point isn't the gates it's the almost non-existent fences that are the week points. If someone wanted to attack this post it would not matter how strict the gates are controlled when they can easily step over the fences. I am not saying these are bad changes to policy but it does make me wonder about the logic behind it.

Can you address all this time and money being spent on this, however one of the locked gates still lets folks walk/bike on and off the installation without any identification check whatsoever?  All this effort and traffic jams, yet we have a poorly locked gate that has access on the left and right side of it for individuals to come and go as they please.
What I dont understand is all the gates that are for DOD only have been impacted by30-50minutes every day this week. Everyone in my office has noticed it since Monday.
This is understandable and protection...which is good...but how about a response to my post about how my sister was delayed an HOUR before getting to my mother in the EMERGENCY ROOM.

Could a clearly stated instruction be posted to your Web and fb page. Specifically covering in detail barney style how to get a pass
 1) as a vendor
2) medical/therapy provider
3) as a worker and what the host company needs to do
4) covering family and friends who visit
and the specific forms available for print with applicable check list. 
The process if we plan to have a group of people come and get them pre-cleared (weddings, birthday parties, etc). 

Please also post the information regarding the process to follow when the AIE system does not recognize your military ID card or other authorized pass. 

The lack of information available has many getting confused or told something different when we talk to the guards or go into the Visitor Center .
Advance notice would have been nice instead of inconsistent, random enforcement of new policy...

What are visitors supposed to do on weekends when the visitor's center at Tulley is closed?  There seemed to be a lot of confusion about this last weekend and the information on the Ft. Belvoir web-site is not clear.

I think Fort Belvoir should make it illegal to turn right into Pence gate from the Route 1 light heading into Pence gate.  There are many individuals who are bypassing the normal right hand lane of traffic by turning at that light.  Their actions are delaying entry onto base even longer for those who are traveling north on Route 1 from Tulley.  I also think changing the stop sign entering Pence gate from Route 1 to a yield sign would help things along as well.  I understand everyone is frustrated with the situation and trying desperately to get to work, but let's try to highlight problem areas that need fixing.  That may just help traffic somewhat.

This doesn't just affect those people trying to get onto Ft Belvoir.  This is affecting the entire area surrounding Ft Belvoir who can't get to work, appts, school because we can't get past Belvoir.  We don't have many options to get past Belvoir to where we need to go.  All the Belvoir traffic is blocking through traffic on the surrounding roads.
Will some sort of security be provided for the gate in Lewis village? Our children go to a school right next to an unsecured location, something has to happen with that..

I no longer have a military id but my kids who are 13 & 10 do. Only reason I go to Belvoir is to take my kids to the hospital. It took me over 30mins to get to the hospital. I haven't been to Belvoir in while after getting to check point at the main gate we were turned away told to go to Tulley gate, it's not far but with traffic an the lights took tens mins. Going to that visitor center is worst than going to the dmv. The people are just as nasty Mr. Kenneth Bissell (probably spelled his name wrong) he was a jerk. I asked "how long will this process take I need to get my kids to the hospital" his response "i don't know" I asked " 5 mins, 10mins" his response "I don't know but you can't stand here" then proceeded to talk about me as of I couldn't hear. There should be an easier process for parents to get to the hospital. Think about it your kid is vomiting, has a fever last thing you want to do is drag your kid in pain out of the car to the visitor center have to fill out paper work, wait, get paper work back, wait some more, take a freaking picture, wait for your paper to print then walk back out to your car, get back in line to drive thru the check point to drive half way across the base to get to the hospital. To make it better this pass I was given is only valid at Tulley gate!!!
It's about time! On Fort Bragg they search your car if you don't have ID....

If you guys have concerns about issues you would like to see addressed, please submit issues to AFAP at the ACS building or online.  I sat as a delegate just last week at this year's AFAP conference, and we did address an issue with Meeres Gate (the one someone referenced that is close to the school and the commissary that is not terribly secure).  Our workgroup considered it to have wide enough impact on the Belvoir community that it was chosen to go before Garrison Command for review.  All of the issues are read and taken very seriously!  We have subject matter experts come in and advise on the current situation, regs, etc.  And even if your issue isn't formally addressed, we are still obligated to write a disposition paper on every single issue raised at AFAP, which the Garrison Commander receives.  This year we received over 50 issues.

While it was not an easy one, the decision to close Walker Gate on weekends was based on actual volume compared to other available gates on Saturdays and Sundays. As with all of our resources, we must allocate them in the most efficient and effective manner possible. The traffic volume does not support the current schedule. Belvoir continues to recruit and hire Dept. of the Army Security Guards to operate access control points on post. Despite these efforts, the Directorate of Emergency Services has yet to reach the total number of authorized guards due to attrition. As a result, guards have been working mandatory overtime. This is unsustainable, both from a morale and a fiscal standpoint. In order to reduce the strain on the guards and reduce attrition of the force, DES was forced to curtail operations.

Why doesn't this garrison seek community input before announcing decisions like this? Not only is this an inconvenience to those who live on post, it is announced with no reason stated. I realize I may be shooting my foot here, but as a "Walker Gate resident", dependent, and DoD Civilian I am bummed about the inconvenience of utilizing Pence during Sat and Sun outings, however,   it's not that bad. As residents I don't think we should fight the issue with our installation. On post housing is privatized and what i would consider to be a privelige we choose to take advantage of or not. While I do think our opinions and valid concerns matter, perhaps you are shooting the messenger here. Maybe not having 5 gates available at any given time, for an open installation, is really that important to you and you feel that the lack of accessability decreases your family's quality of life. If so consider submitting an Army Family Action Plan issue formally. Or submit an ICE comment. The way I see it, it's going to be an inconvenience but not a deal breaker for me and my family. We are seeing a slow decline in having access to the gate closest to our home...but what are we if we can't be resilient to changes in our everyday lives? My QOL issues are more with our dwindling Healthcare options than the part time closing of a gate.

They, the men and women of the United States Armed Forces,  do now as they have done in the past, and will do in the future, go into harms way because that what they are ordered to do. Some go because they feel it is just, others go because they swore an oath, but all go because it is their duty. They go to protect and defend the rights and freedom of our country although some of the reasons our nation's leaders chose to send them are highly questionable. None of them return home the same person they were before they journeyed into harm's way. Some went to fight for God, family and country, some for retribution and others for one reason or another. However, in the true battles, they fought for one another. The man or woman to their left or right, their Brothers and Sisters in Arms! This Memorial Day weekend, remember those who fell and pay tribute to their memories and the sacrifice they made. Say a silent prayer for them and salute them, but also remember their families, friends and their Brothers and Sisters in Arms who now feel that void in their souls for a son or daughter,  father or mother, a comrade that will stand no more among them, but will live on as a cherished memory. Remember also the brave souls who did return in the ranks of the living because they will continue to stand their post, whether at home or in harm's way, guardians of our liberties and freedoms.

[My Memorial Day 2015 status update]

Dear civilians, 

Please pardon an old Army veteran for intruding upon the first day of your summer vacation season:

I happened upon Private Gilmer W. White's grave over four years ago while looking around the small cemetery of my great-grandmother's small church in rural Stokes County.  Having served my first assignment with the 3rd Infantry Division (Marne Division) in Cold War Germany, during which I shared a kaserne with the 1st Battalion of the 7th Infantry Regiment (Cottonbalers), upon reading "7 INF 3 INF DIV," I exclaimed, "Cottonbaler! Rock of the Marne!"  When I read the date of death, I instinctively snapped to attention and rendered a hand salute.  I knew that the 3rd ID had been fighting its way through southern France from the late summer of 1944 through the early winter of 1945, so I realized that Private White had been killed in action.  All I know of him is what is on his marker, but I suppose he was just a Stokes County farm boy . . . 

Freedom isn't free . . .

Old men forget; yet all shall be forgot,
But he'll remember, with advantages,
What feats he did that day. Then shall our names,
Familiar in his mouth as household words?
. . .
From this day to the ending of the world
But we in it shall be remember?d,
We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.
For he today that sheds his blood with me
Shall be my brother...

Rock of the Marne!
This We'll Defend!

? Sergeant James Matthew Wallace, U.S. Army (1985-1993), Honorably Discharged  

Unit Armorer (May 1986 - April 1988)
HQ & A Company, 26th Forward Support Battalion 
(was 3rd FSB prior to April 1987 redesignation)
3rd Infantry Division (Mechanized)
Aschaffenburg-am-Main, Bavaria, FRG

I think the extent that BAH will pay for is often overestimated. If you take your BAH out in town you will not be receiving a manicured lawn, electricity, water, free plumbing/ air/ carpentry repairs, trash pickup... sure we "pay" for these services, but at a ridiculous fraction of what it would cost to have the services rendered off- post. Dawn Garay Dean - Your homeowners' association sounds fab. At mine in Woodbridge, we get garbage removal and occasional grass-cutting in common areas. This season, it also took forever for them to cut the grass for the first time, as we were soggy, as I expect it was on Fort Belvoir.

A dog-walking 'station' was promised almost 2 years ago and still none exist. How hard can installing one of 2 of them really be? We'd have garbage removal, just paying a refuse company directly if we didn't have a HOA. For me, I am not getting my money's worth out of HOA fees. Just do not see a benefit. But - good for you - really! 

Some residents of any military installation fuss about amenities, like dog parks, walking trails, shuttle services, pools and community gardens, and then don't use them when they're created. Some also don't know how good they have it or that they can try to afford to live off post. Luck to all.

It is important to remember that Fort Belvoir is not a locked post (no perimeter fencing around every inch) and it's easy to have a false sense of security. There are multiple points of access that cannot be monitored 24/7. Vehicle entry is monitored, but people can walk or bike on at many other points. People could even gain entry from the water. Always be aware of your surroundings, and don't take safety for granted.

We have been stationed at Fort Belvoir two times, total of 5 years. Both times we chose to live on base, due to the horror of having to commute. The places that traffic is bottlenecked on route 1 is still the same (@FC parkway, Lorton at the 95S on ramp, all through Woodbridge because of lights and reduced speed, Dumfries). We have seen progress since our return to the area with the connection of FC Parkway from Belvoir North to FS Parkway and now the exspansion of HOV lanes on 95 and I assume exspansion on route 1 (there are signs up for work taking place starting this month), exspansions on I66 toward Manassas, HOV lanes on I395. Things are progressing and at the pace one would expect. One thing that I would love to see, since my husband is commuting to his office this time around is earlier busses and trains leaving Springfield Station. To arrive at his unit in time for PT, he has to leave to catch the earliest busses and trains available now. Earlier ones would give more time to arrive and not be rushed.

"OPM?s history begins with the Civil Service Act, signed in 1883, ending the spoils system and establishing the Civil Service Commission.  The Commission, led by the energetic Teddy Roosevelt, laid the foundations of an impartial, professional civil service based on the merit principle ? that employees should be judged only on how well they can do the job.

In 1978, the Civil Service Commission was reorganized into three new organizations: the Office of Personnel Management, the Merit Systems Protection Board, and the Federal Labor Relations Authority.  Each of these new organizations took over a portion of the Civil Service Commission?s responsibilities, with OPM responsible for personnel management of the civil service of the Government."

The support center is a mission activity that isn't open to the public. Their job is to store and care for the artifacts until they can be featured in a museum setting.
We've driven by this place hundreds of times.  Thanks for giving us a glimpse inside.  What a spectacular place the museum will be once it is finally built!!

"So what do you have to do to be able to see all the wonderful things that are stored?"  That is an extremely loaded question, but here's the short of it:  Some of you may recall the museum that was on Ft. Myer and housed some awesome relics (now stored on Belvoir) and great history of it and The Old Guard (as well as other portions of the Army if I'm not mistaken).  It was closed a few (5+?) years ago due to space issues.  Plans were drawn up to redo and add space (an additional floor, I think) to Ft. Myer's Town Hall (former theatre) to house the museum, but the economy tanked and funds weren't available.  So, if you happen to have a load of cash laying around and/or the time to devote to heading up a fundraising effort, contact the folks over at Ft. Myer!  :-)  (And let me know how I can help!)

Not sure what folks off post do, particularly those who live in close-in town house communities. Ultimately the issue is between residents and the landlord (Michaels in the case of The Villages). Recommend bringing the issue up with the Community Manager for your neighborhood.

There needs to be a standard side of the street to park on.  Not all vehicles fit in garages - they barely fit 2 "regular" size cars, forget trucks.  We have to park our vehicles at an angle and one head in one head out in order to use the garage.  And many of the so called driveways are non-existent - 3 or 4 feet of concrete does not a driveway make.  If there was a standard side to park on - like opposite the side with fire hydrants then at least we would have a decent path for the plows.  This would also help in everyday drive-ability of the housing areas.  The streets are narrow in general , so there should be one side parking all the time.

I fit 2 Large Trucks in my garage on post. They fit fine. Parking lessons may need to be on the offering list of the MWR. Lol. Also, the neighborhood offices should probably enforce the standards in the lease agreements. Garages are for cars. Not storage space. That's what the "attic" space in the area ABOVE the garage floor ;)

Just an FYI, most insurance companies will not cover your vehicle if it was damaged because you did not yield to an emergency vehicle. This includes being parked. Pence Gate has to remain open around the clock, to provide the most direct access to the hospital & ER there.

To reiterate, the change to gate hours at Telegraph is the result of adjusting hours to the number of authorized Dept. of the Army Security Guards we are allowed to employ. This is complicated by the fact that recruiting and retaining guards is a constant challenge. Further, gate statistics are tracked and analyzed. Usage of Telegraph before 6 a.m. and after 6 p.m. indicates this adjustment impacts the smallest number of commuters. We realize that for those affected by the change find it inconvenient. Previously when Walker Gate hours were trimmed, there were similar issues. We don't receive funding to allow us to keep every gate open for the duration we know our community desires. This change mitigates the impact to the greatest extent possible when compared to other possible scenarios.
This really stinks especially since it is the best gate to get to kingstowne and for my husband to get home from work.

Those of us who use the gates - more to the point, the numbers of us, and the times we enter and exit - are, of course, taken into account when these decisions are made. So, too, are the numbers of guards and dollars available, as well as the other requirements that must be fulfilled at the gates. I think we need to keep in mind that ...

* Neither Kingman nor Telegraph is set up for anything other than passenger vehicles. (The ADFE facility has its own gate directly off Telegraph.)

* Tulley is the Visitor gate, and, the only gate configured for security processing of delivery trucks. (Consider those drivers pulling huge daily loads to the PX and Commissary who have to go through Tulley to get to destinations that are just inside Kingman.)

* Pence is primary gate for the hospital, and, Walker is a key school bus gate serving the South Post neighborhoods.

It's an understandable and reasonable enough question to ask, "Why not that way instead of this way?" But, that VERY question was part of the decision-making process in the first place. How best to deploy the number of available guards without closing a gate COMPLETELY was and is the #1 consideration. That said, it's also reasonable to expect more adjustments later as Mulligan Road opens and Telegraph is widened, and, once the new gate into North Post off Route 1 (opposite Pence) opens next year.

I suggest adding a half hour on each end, opening at 0530 and closing at 1830.  I understand budget cuts/ limited resources, but bottom line 0600 to 1800 does not support personnel who work at the Pentagon and take the Metro.  I believe most of us could make it to the gate after 0530 and get back by 1830; however 0600 to 1800 would cause most of us to miss one or both those times, thereby making an already tough commute that much harder.  Thanks for your consideration/ what you do.

Congress' National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013 established a nine-member Military Compensation and Retirement Modernization Commission. The Commission's task is to review the military compensation and retirement programs and make recommendations for their modernization to the President and Congress in the Spring of 2014. The goal of the Commission's recommendations will be to ensure the long-term health of the All-Volunteer Force, provide for a high quality-of-life for the members of the Uniformed Forces and their families, and make sure that the compensation and retirement programs are financially sustainable.

Tips to remember: Always yield to pedestrians who may be
crossing the road on your approach to a roundabout.
Pedestrians, bicycle riders and motorcyclists are
often very hard to see, so always watch for them.
Buses and trucks may need more than one lane to
enter or leave a roundabout, so keep clear of them.
Always yield to vehicles that are in the roundabout.

Why can't they paint arrows on the ground and post a sign?  I'll gladly go paint them myself.  It's rely not that hard to use the correct lanes, but it seems most of Belvoir has no clue how to use the traffic circle.
In reference to the Pence Gate roundabout...I wish people would stop trying to make right hand turns from the left lane when in the roundabout. Ive been almost hit a handful of times that way.
This is what they need out there at Pence gate....  It's not a difficult concept.

Cracks me up how angry people get about roundabouts. I'd much rather have a roundabout than a stop light, at least the traffic keeps flowing. Drivers just need to remember that if you plan to exit immediately, stay in the right lane and use your directional. Those entering the roundabout need to yield...traffic in the rotary has the right of way, for some reason drivers here don't understand that.
How and why do people think its correct to turn right from the left lane???  If you know you are going to turn right, just stay to the right  and use your turn signal!!!!

Leslie Alvarez - Bicycle registration is available at the Visitors Processing Center at Tulley Gate. Anyone who lives on Fort Belvoir may register their bikes. They need to come in with their Military ID and complete a form, which includes the bicycle's make, model, type, color & serial number. Once they are registered, owners get a decal to put on their bike.   The registration process takes no more than 5 minutes. Happy riding!

There are no gates, per se, for any housing area anywhere. the gates are there for the mission resources (i.e., Soldiers, employees, buldings). The Commissary, however, as a DOD activity with federal employees, will close on Mondays. Candice N. For Huntington and Belle View/New Alexandria residents  - Based on the latest forecast, if the area gets 2 inches of rain, especially over a short time, residents could experience significant street flooding in the Huntington area.  As a precaution, Huntington residents should move their vehicles to higher elevations. County officials also note that residents may experience localized street flooding in the Belle View/New Alexandria areas. However, structural flooding in the Huntington or Belle View/New Alexandria areas is not anticipated now.

Barbara Hewett Worley, the law applies except for legally parked or legally stopped out of the flow of traffic. While at a stop sign or light you are still to be attentive to traffic.

Samantha Torres, the law applies to actively texting or reading texts. Any task that averts your eyes from the road, even for a second, constitutes distracted driving. From the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles: Here are some distracted driving facts for 2012 in Virginia:
?Most distracted driving crashes involved drivers 21 to 35 years old
?Most distracted driver crashes occurred at the end of the week on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, between noon and 6 p.m.
?The top three driver distractions last year were, in order: ?drivers not having their eyes on the road
?fatigue
?cell phone use

Kelly Gillespie Sutterfield, While Virginia law prohibits texting and driving, there is no restriction on cell phone use. It is against Department of Defense policy to use a cell phone while driving unless it is hands free. Belvoir Police must follow Virginia law to issue U.S. Magistrate ticket, which carries a fine. They may issue a Department of Defense Form 1408, Armed Forces Traffic Ticket, which will be forwarded to the offender's organization. To alert Belvoir Police of ongoing speeding issues, you may call 703-806-5601.

Courtney Davis, the Garrison Commander may revoke post driving privileges for accumulation of three tickets in a 12-month period. There are other circumstances under which priviliges may be revoked. We asked the Exchange about the timing of the grand opening. One issue, of course, is juggling all the different calendars of the officials who have to be there, and finding a date that matches. But, the Exchange people tell us there's a more important reason. Many years of lessons learned have taught them that there is no such thing as a "best" time. But, they do it like this to have a couple days with customers to shake out the bugs before the really BIG rush of customers comes in on the first weekend. Sure enough, today, there was a glitch with cash register software that was to have downloaded from AAFES over night that didn't download. Result? A brief pause at all registers this morning until the problem got fixed. That sort of thing is what they want to be able to identify and correct before the really really BIG crowds show up on the weekend.

The Installation's leadership and operations center continue to monitor the weather forecasts. Should the weather impact the operational status of facilities and services, that information will be provided as appropriate via e-mail; Fort Belvoir's social media site; Belvoir Online at www.belvoir.army.mil; and, recorded on the info hotline at (703) 805-3030. Information is also available on AM radio at AM1610 for those within five miles of the post. When necessary, information about weather impacts on Fort Belvoir operations is also provided to local area TV and radio stations. Should a weather emergency occur, your first rule of thumb if at all in doubt about your duty status is to ask your supervisor. Supervisors should double-check their internal alert-notification rosters now should it become necessary to activate them.

Customers may experience early closure of services such as Child, Youth and School Services, ID Card Section, SJA Services due to the early dismissal. Customers should call ahead to determine availability of services. Parents of children in Child Development Centers will be notified of early dismissal, however CDCs will remain open until all children have been picked up. ALL CYSS programs for this evening have been cancelled. Employees of mission partner/tenant organizations unclear of their duty status should contact their supervisors.

I'm washing all our laundry today so I don't have mountains to do later like the last summer. Flashlights and candles are ready too!

Thankfully I have a gas stove so I make sure I have matches (plus candles for light).  I tank my A/C to run low through most of the day so when (it's never an if) we lose power my place stays mostly cool for more than a few hours.  Gallons of water thrown into the freezer and pre-cooked most of the foods that wil spoil within hours of lost power (eggs and such).
We froze a case of bottled water.  That way I can leave it in the freezer to keep it cold, as well as have cold water to drink.
See also the good advice at http://www.acsim.army.mil/readyarmy/.

Fort Belvoir?s leadership and staff continue to monitor the weather. Any updates on impacts to the operating status of installation services and facilities will be provided as appropriate. Employees with any doubt as to their duty status should check with their supervisor.

Fire Dept says Mount Vernon Road is now clear and reopened. But, Dominion Power may need a lane to work on the downed line once their heavy trucks arrive. Would be near the Mount Vernon and Hurley intersection. Drivers best advised to us alternate routes where possible - be alert to crews.

The affected area extends the length of Beulah Road, from the gate at Telegraph, alongside the golf course, to the Nolan Building, crossing the intersection at Kingman Road. Drivers can expect at least one lane to be closed at any given time as it is milled, then paved. Major impact is to outgoing traffic bound for the Telegraph Road gate.

During the period of this work, the crews and traffic officials urge drivers leaving North Post that would normally use Telegraph Gate to leave via Kingman Gate instead. South Post traffic that usually crosses via Gunston Road to Kingman to exit through Telegraph should instead leave via Pence, Tulley or Walker Gate on South Post.

Ladies - Resiliency training is usually scheduled for the 2 days right after each month's newcomer's briefing (which was this morning.) There's a formula for the newcomer's briefing schedule - it's the Tuesday after the 10th of any month. (Soldiers often have to report on the 10th of any month to their new duty station, if you're shaking your head.) Best to start the inquiry at ACS, 805 4590, or Belvoir's Headquarters Battalion. Good luck, thanks for your interest and STAY RESILIENT!!!!

All routine and acute appointments as well as elective surgeries are cancelled. Please contact the clinic where you originally scheduled your appointment to reschedule, or call the Integrated Referral Management Appointing Center at 855-227-6331 upon reopening of the federal government. Emergency Room services remain open. Emergency employees will report for work as scheduled. Staff who are unsure of their status as Emergency Employees, have questions about the operating status of their department or who have difficulty reporting must contact their immediate supervisor.

I've lived and commuted in Los Angeles and the SF Bay area before I PCS'd to Belvoir last year.  Which is why I decided to live north of post so I would have a reverse commute ... I have no complaints about the traffic. :-)

I say it has gotten worse for me, especially in the last year. I travel from western Lake Ridge and it's about 14 miles one way. That isn't a long commute in miles but it takes me about 45 minutes on average in bumper to bumper traffic to arrive at Tulley Gate, and about an hour on average to drive home in the afternoon. People drive horribly, trying to get one or two cars ahead, and the congestion just wears you down. I can't even say there is one specific part of my commute that I dislike. It is the same driving condition every bit of the way. And there isn't a faster route because everyone else is trying to find a faster route. And I almost never see any carpooling happening. One person per car, the same cars everyday...It hurts. An Omni bus route from Lake Ridge to Pence Gate would work wonders, IMO. I would take it just to avoid the stress of constant defensive driving.

Might I ask why the gate closest to three of the major housing areas is shortening weekend hours when residents would be in and out the most?

Kurt, it's a question of available staffing and usage rates at all gates on the weekends. As you know, Walker Gate during the week is an especially busy gate for traffic entering post not just for River, GW and Dogue Creek, but the other neighborhoods on South Post, as well as service facilities like the hospital, Military Personnel, CPAC, DFAS, the post office and the Officers Club. That usage drops dramatically on the weekends, however, to a point below usage at Pence and Tulley Gates. That's basis for the decision to close Walker overnight on Saturday and Sunday, leaving it still operational for 12 hours on those days, and 24 hours Monday-Friday.

As Fort Belvoir completes the transition from contract security personnel to Department of the Army security guards, DES must adjust some aspects of access control. The Army authorizes fewer security guards for Fort Belvoir than had been provided under the contract, which will end this Saturday. As a result, gate staffing must be adjusted to get the most out of the available manpower provided by the Army. Although we have been fortunate in hiring security guards more rapidly than we initially calculated, we will still be under our authorized strength when the changeover is completely in place on Saturday. We anticipate reaching our full authorized strength shortly. Access control will present challenges during the transition as we work to decide the best possible deployment of the gate guard force. We are confident we will strike the right balance.
Thanks for the quick response and explanation.  Sounds like there was some analysis done and it makes sense.

Thank you for doing the same thing my Dad; CSM JB Brown did for me in high school - to keep me focused and engaged in something that would give me and my Spirit a Freedom it so needed at that time in my Life. For military personnel and employees at Fort Belvoir, your supervisory chain is your best first stop for information about impact on the duty status of your office or unit. Supervisors should ensure their alert-notification rosters are up-to-date and ready to be activated. Employees with the slightest doubt as to their duty status should contact their supervisor.

Fort Belvoir operating status is also provided to the local television and radio stations whose Web links are provided below. In addition to running weather-status announcements in their on-air broadcasts, most media outlets also list them in ?Operating Status? links on their Web sites. Please note that when events are significant, literally HUNDREDS of organizations in Virginia, Maryland, D.C., West Virginia and Pennsylvania submit their status to the media. The more notices there are, the less frequently any one notice is announced. In some events, it may be a half hour or longer between the times when Fort Belvoir?s status appears or is heard.

Question, if the roads go black, but I am in a critical position and either on my way to work, or back home from work would I have any issues at the gate? I work at the Pentagon, and live on Belvoir, I do have the 3 on my Pentagon badge but I doubt that anyone on the gates at Belvoir know what that means.

James, we asked DES and here's what they said: "In the unlikely event the installation declares all the roads black, the
gate guard will inform residents that the roads are impassable or limited to emergency traffic only. Gates will remain staffed and each situation will be handled on a case-by-case basis. If it is determined a vehicle operator can make it to where they're going, he or she will be allowed to proceed. You are correct that the installation does not recognize the Pentagon badge codes. However, if you are leaving the installation enroute to the Pentagon, we will not prevent you
from doing so."

OK so no issues then since most of the gate guards already know me and how I have my vehicle set up for winter. Growing up in snow country and being stationed at Fort Drum gets you very prepared for winter. Thank you for your time in finding this out for me. Ice would be the primary way I could see the roads going black, and I am properly set up for that with my tires and optional equipment.

Someone should post how to correctly go about the traffic circle. I've almost been hit tons of times already because of the yield and improper use of it.

How about the improper lane change within the circle. So many times I see someone swerve across the lanes, no blinker, cutting someone else off. If you miss your turn, oh well, its a fricken circle and you will have another chance. Don't cut someone else off just because you're in a hurry.

http://www.virginiadot.org/info/faq-roundabouts.asp 

This is the actual law regarding two laned traffic circles.
Also don't turn right when ur in the inside lane to go out pence gate! I've seen at least 4 wrecks and alot of near misses because people don't know how to drive.
Also if drivers would signal when exiting the circle as well..
Turn signals are key in that circle. You ARE authorized to take the inside lane and turn right towards pence gate.
Lets face it, people aren't smart/mature enough for traffic circles, especially ones as small as the one at Pence.  Who else predicted this was a bad idea before the construction was completed?
Also, yielding =/= stopping when there is NO traffic already in the circle.

as far as rotaries go this one is small, and would normally be located in a residential area, it seems as if as soon as I have entered the circle, move to the inside lane that it is already time for me to exit, can you expand this rotary in any way, maybe do away with the inside lane and just use the outside...
Correct Nick, but you do not have the right of way over traffic in the OUTSIDE lane whilst doing so.

You can change lanes on a roundabout, but use your mirrors and indicators, just as you would on a road, both lanes can be used when exiting pence as it is two lane road exit. Right lane right turn, left lane left turn, not hard to figure out!
Actually Erik you would. Due to yielding to the right of way that " may constitute hazard"
Just amazed this had to be posted.    Too bad there is not an app for it... Or is there?
The outside lane can ONLY turn right or go straight.  The inside lane may go straight, left or do a u-turn.  It says so in the VDOT info.

Tickets cost $45 each, and can be purchased at all Philadelphia-area Ticketmaster outlets, online at http://www.ticketmaster.com or by calling Ticketmaster at 1-800-745-3000. Active duty military will receive a $10 discount by showing military I.D. at the Lincoln Financial Field box-office or by calling the box office at 215-463-2300 on Friday, December 7 and on game day as availability permits.

This year?s Army-Navy Game marks the 113th edition of the interservice rivalry and the 84th game to be played in Philadelphia. The kickoff at Lincoln Financial Field is scheduled for 3:00 p.m. on December 8, and the game will be televised nationally by CBS and carried by Sirius Satellite Radio and Dial Global Radio. Locally, the game will be broadcast live on CBS-3 TV and 950AM ESPN.

Applicants and their sponsor must be enrolled in the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System database and have a current military ID card. Laura Shafer Burrow, while it is frustrating, work to the power grid must be done sequentially in order to energize the grid safely. If a repair is not made at one point in the line before another, workers could inadvertently send power to a broken line. This is dangerous and potentially damaging to the system. Crews will continue to work for the next couple of hours and there is some potential for additional restoration. The extent of possible restoration is governed by what difficulties they may encounter. We hope for significant progress through the day and evening tomorrow.

Russ Sauers many of the places work is necessary are on off-road right-of-ways you and a standard road vehicle wouldn't be able to access. It is not as simple as just coming to base and turning power on. They have to start at the plant and work there way down the lines, so if your looking for them there's nothing that can be done right away it takes time and supplies. They have people do assessments and then tell crews what is needed and where.  They also start with critical loads first and houses are not part of it, mostly shelters, hospitals, and emergency management areas.

Lionel Norman, there is prioritization and there is order of work. In some cases, something that seems inconsequential will have to be restored before something more critical down the line can be restored. This could be a multi-day restoration event as predicted before the storm. Notes from The Villages at Belvoir indicate neighborhood centers are available as respite from the outage.

Dominion crews, in concert with Belvoir's Directorate of Public Works and Emergency Services personnel are working to restore power.  As learned in Derecho, it is extremely difficult to predict how long this might take. As predicted heading into the storm, thousands across the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast are without power this morning. It could take several days until restoration is complete.
Many questions have been posted to many different comment threads. We will attempt to provide timely, accurate and relevant information regarding recovery efforts on post. Refrain from posting questions to comments on a different topic. Feel free to direct message us for a reply. It is best to visit the main Belvoir Facebook presence to see if your question has already been answered. For those who may not have it, the page is www.facebook.com/fortbelvoir.

Please be patient. Most services and facilities are not available at Fort Belvoir today. If it is not a matter of life, health, safety or critical military mission, it is likely closed today. If you are not on Belvoir working and not a resident, it is best not to travel to post today except for legitimate emergencies.

Updates will be provided as they are available.
Any word on the CDC and whether it will reopen tomorrow?Will it be posred here or some other site? Thanks

Arcelia Wicker Jr, information will be posted at www.facebook.com/fortbelvoir and on the main page www.belvoir.army.mil as with all previous updates. As discussed in other posts, it is still too early to tell what will be restored and what will not. Stay tuned to the main facebook page by visiting it frequently as not all updates appear in your newsfeed. Likewise, our status updates may answer questions you have.

I thought I should share my hurricane/power outage prep tip since we have plenty of advanced warning.  If you don?t have a generator you can fill up containers of water and put them in your freezer now.  Bump the temp as low as it can go and pack it up tight.  If the power is out for an extended period the ice packs should keep it cold for a long while.  No mess with leaky bags of ice.

First and foremost, I would like to say the Army Civilian is the backbone of the Army. Go DACs!!! While I respect our leaders for making the tough decision to draw down the force, I believe that little attention has been paid to the ramifications. Within the Department of the Army these reductions are not just affecting the Soldiers but, the civilian workforce as well at a time in the United States when there are minimal jobs available. So essentially we are telling our Soldiers, thank you for your service and enjoy unemployment for as long as it last because, while we cared for you on active duty we failed to take care of the economy so their are no jobs when you come home. I'm not saying that we need to foot the bill for all veterans however, if we are discharging someone for not making rank or being substandard, what makes you believe that these individuals will not further hinder the economy. To sum up my point, we are not in the era following WWII when jobs were in abundance after the war, we are in the age of offshoring and importation of goods from other nations leaving no jobs in America. Think about that before making all your cuts and what your impact could be if you had to call these individuals back, for example after President Clinton's drawdown. Do you think they would all answer the call to duty like after 9/11 if America has not taken care of them when they most needed it?

I am sad because it's not like the va system has been taking care of soldiers but now they will quickly put them through the system and not there problem! I pray we won't need more anytime soon after they push them out!

I am concerned some Staff Sergeants that consider themselves great leaders still make the horrible mistake of calling Soldiers Bodies, This whole down size plan was ill conceived poorly planned and did not consider the ramifications on the employment pool, which is already small as it is. Lets not also forget that some of these Soldiers being let go are also being lost in a system wrought with high suicide rates and murder, go figure though. not the Armys problem since you were kicked out though.

The Veterans Crisis Line connects Veterans in crisis and their families and friends with qualified, caring Department of Veterans Affairs responders through a confidential, toll-free hotline, online chat, or text. Veterans and their loved ones can call 1-800-273-8255 and Press 1; chat online through http://www.veteranscrisisline.net/; or send a text message to 838255 to get confidential support 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year.

I was at the clinic on Bolling AFB, and I laughed at the extreme overreaction of all the folks around here. They evacuated buildings and did head counts after that mini-quake! You could barely feel it and people acted as if they were going to be swallowed by the earth. If you want a REAL earthquake, go to CA or Japan. That "quake" was just the trial version.

Sitting in our lovely trailers here on Belvoir when they started bouncing (God love trailers); people started bolting, I ducked under the desk to wait the ride out.  Walked outside and shook my head at the fact that people ran outside toward the power lines.  How do most people get injured during earthquakes?  Oh, right, falling debris and falling power lines.  Thank goodness I grew up on an island in Alaska and all over the west coast where we had earthquake drills lol.  I will say though, probably the funniest thing I'd ever seen in my life was people's reaction.

My husband was deployed I had just fell asleep. By the time my brain figured out what was going on and I ran to get my boys to get in a doorway it was over. Go ahead and make fun of us who went outside to figure out what was going on....laugh away if it makes you feel better. I had never been in a earthquake before. It scared me and I still could not believe it when I went outside to try and figure out exactly what was going on.

We were actually in the process of moving here from CA...we were like "great, we're trading in one earthquake zone for another..."  Honestly though, we've done the earthquake thing in CA, the "worst" one set off the fire alarm, waking my then toddler out of her nap...other than that, no harm done

Ive lived in california my whole life and never experienced an earthquake so it scared me too even though i knew what to do. By the tine i realized what was happening and got to my babies, it was over. Did walk outside after to make sure it had really happened and i wasnt losing my mind, bc yknow who ever hears about earthquakes in va!?

My son was picking his story for nap time and I was putting away laundry...... When I realized what was going on I scooped my son up flew down the stairs and out the door there are no power lines outside our house so yep I wasn't waiting to catch the inside of the house:)

We just moved to Ft. Belvoir from Alaska where earthquakes are common.  We were in Target on Route 1 in the checkout line and had just finished paying when it hit. People were yelling, tiles were falling off the ceiling and you could hear things falling on the floor; it felt like a truck hit the building. My kids and I just looked at each other and said "oh, it's an earthquake." Both of them being born and raised in Alaska, it wasn't a big deal. We just laughed and joked about how earthquakes must have followed us here:)
In line at Tulley Gate. I just thought I was having engine trouble. Didn't figure out what happened until I got to the office (Earthquake? Awesome - that saved me some money on repairs.)

I was under my desk in a 2nd floor office at Fort Belvoir. Hard to do in heels! Overheard a co-worker say, 'That's an earthquake.'  Had always wanted to experience an earthquake - now, that fix is done and I could do without other 'experiences.'

Early this morning a Code was announced at the hospital as a precautionary measure to protect patients and staff from a potentially dangerous situation. The code was called shortly after staff alerted security personnel that a person entered the hospital carrying what appeared to be a weapon resembling a shotgun. All medical staff and security personnel responded appropriately by moving to their observation posts and securing all entrance/exits to the facility. Security then located the individual and learned that it was a patient carrying a dummy rifle used for training. Security determined that there was no threat, and the All Clear signal was announced. In this particular case, medical staff responded quickly to the Code in an effort to protect patients and staff. This is a strong reminder that we can face a potentially dangerous situation at any moment, and that we must all be prepared to do our part during an emergency situation. (Fort Belvoir Community Hospital Public Affairs)

When I viewed my house I noticed that there was a glade plug-in in the wall, and it made the house smell kind of gross. When we moved in I burned candles all the time, but when I had my son I didn't feel safe using candles. I now sell a product called Scentsy, and with the recent fire on Belvoir, I thought I should share it with everyone. Scentsy is a safe alternative to candles, it uses a bulb not a flame. It is safe around babies, and pets. The wax used is food grade so if baby or pet decided to eat it they wouldn't get sick! All you do is plug the ceramic warmer into the wall, turn the switch on, and place your Scentsy wax in the removable top dish, and thats it! There are over 80 scents, and they are all currently on sale! So if you live on Belvoir, you have kids and or pets, and you don't like candles because of the risk of fire, please check out my website, EmilysCommonScents.Scentsy.US, and shop my end of summer party. US Code 36 Chapter 10, section 171 Conduct During Playing: "During rendition of the national anthem when the flag is displayed, all present except those in uniform should stand at attention facing the flag with the right hand over the heart. Men not in uniform should remove their headdress with their right hand and hold it at the left shoulder, the hand being over the heart. Persons in uniform should render the military salute at the first note of the anthem and retain this position until the last note. When the flag is not displayed, those present should face toward the music and act in the same manner they would if the flag were displayed there."

Doesn't say anything about singing....so it appears to be winners choice.

The list of tax-exempt items is the same as last year and includes such products as pens, pencils, loose leaf ruled notebook paper, scissors, binders, backpacks, construction paper, sneakers, dresses, jeans and T-shirts. An all-inclusive list of school supplies, a list of exempt clothing and footwear items, holiday guidelines for shoppers and retailers, and answers to frequently asked questions are available on the Department?s Sales Tax Holiday Information Center at the link above.

As long as each item purchased qualifies for the exemption, there is no limit on the number of items you can buy.  During this sales tax holiday, retailers may also choose to save taxpayers even more by absorbing the sales tax, or paying it themselves, on items that are not eligible for exemption. The retailers must then pay the sales tax themselves on such sales.

After several attempts, the injured bird was captured the next day and taken to a wildlife rehabilitator licensed to care for Bald Eagles for treatment and recovery. Pilcicki and his co-workers want to thank all of the concerned residents who kept watch and reported sightings, which helped them to recover the Bald Eagle.

As a reminder, if anyone sees injured wildlife on post, please do not approach or touch them, as you would put both the animal and yourself at risk. Instead contact the Fort Belvoir Police at (703) 806-3104. Police will contact the appropriate personnel trained to handle wildlife.

Thank you so much for sharing this important reminder. It is a horrific tragedy. Often parents are tired, stressed, and out of sorts. They can forget the child is in the car while distracted with other things. I know it seems inprobable, but this happens EVERY year. A few years ago, there were a rash of cases. Believe it or not, many of the parents honestly forgot the child was in the car with them. Their routines had changed and it threw them off track. PLEASE talk to people who have, or care for, infants and small children and remind them of the dangers. Talking about this can save a life.
There are all kinds of sites out there with tips on how NOT to forget your child is still in the car. For example, http://bit.ly/NxFT4p

Can someone tell me how to get to this field please? I just moved here earlier this year and have no idea where this feild is at.
Allison, here's a guide. http://belvoirmwr.com/docs2012/SE_FreedomFestTabloid_REV.pdf
Its the field right on Route 1. If you are on south post, cross the bridge over Route 1 and take your immediate right. That road leads right to the field.

To get to Fremont Field from South Post go north on Gunston and cross the bridge over Route 1. Take the second right at Goethals and continue until you find parking. From Kingman Gate, follow J.J. Kingman to Gunston, turn right and continue past Abbott Rd. At Goethals, take a left. Fremont field, or P2 as some know it is the open area on the north side of post directly opposite Pence Gate. If all esle fails, follow the sounds of Elvis and the smell of hotdogs. Both are awesome.
I live by the hospital! Is it the feild across the street from the gate?
Oh got it!

Park your car at at the Community Center or the Joann Blanks CDC and there will be crossing guards to get you across Rte 1. There is a bridge to the field and you will beat all of the Goethals and Gunston road traffic on the way back home after the show! ;o

What exactly does this mean?  That those with power will experience flickering or things will not work?  I hope they get power to everyone!

Dominion hopes this approach will restore power to all remaining residents and facilities. This is a huge load for them and not something they normally undertake in one switch. There may be problems beyond the switch that cause flickering and outages, but they believe they will be able to identify them and restore them quickly.
Will that affect the homes that already have power?

There is the possibility of flickering throughout the system, but mostly downtrace from the current switch. That is to say, those currently without power are more susceptible to flickering than those already restored.

Fort Belvoir, thanks for explaining it to us. We should be SO thankful for them sacrificing time with their own familes to work on getting our families more comfortable.
