If they were working for free I would cut them some slack but they are not. They are providing a service that i pay alot of money for and i enjoy seeing them earn it. They live for days like this because they are racking up the overtime.

It doesn't matter how well they get paid to do the job. There are safety procedures that MUST be followed when restoring power. Try working 16 hours on and then only 8 hours off between shifts. Do that 3-4 days in a row in 90+ heat with a feels like temp in the 100's. We don't have the luxury of wearing shorts and a tank top or playing in a sprinkler to cool off. We wear safety gear which is incredibly hot in this weather.

I'm a gas utility worker but the weather we work outside in is the same, educate yourselves to how devastating this storm was before you go bat shit crazy on good, decent, hard working people.

Speaking only for myself, I live for days like this because I understand that the skills that I have worked hard mastering will help make a difference. I bust my ass every time because I know I would want and expect the same for my family should they be in that unfortunate position. Try cutting them some slack because it's the right and decent thing to do. The people making the repairs aren't the people to show anger and indifference to. Also, the paycheck isn't as nice as you think it is, Uncle Sam takes quite a large chunk of it.

Bless your heart Brett. I love the same old, lame old, 'no one forced them to take the job" line. I understand being upset if this were am ordinary storm, but at one point there were 5,000,000 people without power. Crews were called in as far away as Texas to help restore power. It's not as easy as the flick of a switch. There are labor laws that must be followed which delays the process and also ensures safety.
"Tesla was Robbed" :)
Some very ungreatful people on here @Jason and  Brett maybe you should stop thinking about yourself and think of the WTB who could not flush their toilets or take showers.

Brett Thibodeau - by your logic, the deployments of our servicemembers, their loss of limb and life were no sacrifice because your tax dollars paid for them to be in harm's way. They chose to be servicemembers, therfore their service is not a sacrifice. I think we all owe a great deal to those who do dangerous and daunting work on our behalf. From the Soldiers who defend us, to the law enforement who protect us, to the emergency crews who rescue us; we are constantly in debt. Likewise to those who risk their lives, safety and well being to afford us the comforts we have come to expect, we owe respect and debt. I for one am extemely happy to know that there are those who are willing to climb utility poles and wrestle with deadly voltage so I can sit here at my computer and pontificate.

I pay taxes in large part so that my government protects our nation. when soldiers who choose to be soldiers die or get injured while protecting our nation... See where the similarities are? 

You appear to be rather ungrateful and also seem to not recognize that it was an act of nature not seen in these parts in my lifetime. 

The repairs take time and patience, and you sorely lack one of them. Your attack on the power company comes across as an attack on it's workers who are doing everything they can to get the power back on as quickly and safely as possible. Maybe you should do the math so that you can see that it isn't a city problem, it's not a county problem, it's not a state problem. It's a multi state problem, workers are coming from as far as Texas and Canada to help out. 

You can't fix it and it's your right to pontificate and complain, but I don't see how that is helping the situation. 

I guess my sacrifices are unimportant since my pay doesn't come from tax payers. 

Trust me when I tell you this, if the government was supplying your electricity, it would be a months long outage, not merely a week. Sack up soldier and stop attacking hard working private sector people. Feel free to complain to the utility commission if you want to. In Virginia it's the State Corporation Commission.

Child & Youth Services Updates:

The JoAnn Blanks CDC, Bldg. 1207, will be available from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. Because South Post CDC is not yet operational, child care for those patrons will be available at the JBCDC.
North Post CDC will have care available from 6 a.m. top 6 p.m.
The Youth Center will have care available from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m.

Because the School-Age Center is not yet operations, mission-essential patrons of the School-Age Center, K-2nd grade, will have care available at the Soldier & Family Assistance Center, Bldg. 1263, from 7:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Mission-essential patrons of the School-Age Center, 3rd-6th grade, will have care available at the Youth Center, Bldg. 1003, from 6 a.m.-6 p.m.

All other SAC patrons should check Fort Belvoir Facebook regularly for updates on that facility. 

All CYSS staff are to report as scheduled. SPCDC staff report to JoAnn Blanks CDC. SAC staff for K-2nd grade report to the SFAC at 7:30 a.m.; all others to the YC.

Each mission partner organization on post has the authority to make a operating status decision different from that of the Garrison. However, many do follow the Garrison?s status. Everyone needs to take into account the availability of power to their facilities, storm debris on parking lots, and the condition of the roads and intersections on post (traffic lights at this time remain offline and not working). Fort Belvoir does NOT follow operating status decision of the OPM, whose operating status applies ONLY to federal agencies inside the beltway. Supervisors should consult FB Reg 115-1, and ensure their internal notification systems are current. Employees who have the slightest doubt as to their duty status should contact their supervisor.

1- Keeping your food cool.....Keep plenty of ice, if you can't fill your kiddie pool or bathtub with cool water. Buy plenty of Ziploc Bags..... Take one bag and weight it down (rock), then... put the bag you put your food in in that bag and put it in the water. Do this for the food you want to preserve. ** Important, you must add cool water every so often to keep your food cool. This will help with preserving ice and stretching your food supplies.

2- Meat, it is expensive. Preserve your meat by smoking it. It will not last forever, but it will buy you time to eat it. If you need help on this, let me know.

3- Keeping cool, wet your beach towels and drape them over you heads. Find some wind or a source of air flow. This will act like a swamp cooler and keep the sun off of you.

4- Keep hydrated
Hope it helps!

generators are not that expensive.....go to harbor freight in woodbridge and pic one up for $125 that can keep your fridge and a fan running....or for $300-500 you can power a whole lot more....I bought one little over a yr and a half ago for $325 because I was tired of the power situation on this base. Now the wife and kids have been happy since power went out..got TV/internet, Air Conditioner, and the fridge and freezer in garage are all working....it is well worth the money!!! cheaper then a few day saty in a hotel and having to buy groceries again, and any deductable you might have with renters insurance.

You can manually open your garage to get your vehicle out. There is a cord with a red handle attached to your garage door, if your pull on it, it will take the door off the electricial function giving your the ability to manually open and close the garage.

Play outside in the water to stay cool and stay in the shade. If food starts to melt, stop opening the fridge. Only do so when absolutely needed. Cook what you can, the gas is still on. You can still open the grade manually. This is what happens when we rely too much on technology and we forget the simple things.

I'd LOVE to get a team together.  My son is battling AML for a 2nd time.  He's 5.  And he now will have to have a bone marrow transplant.  Only 1% of cancer research goes to childhood cancer.  Because of this and his relapse, they have to "wing" this next few rounds of chemo because there is NOT enough research out there!!  If you'd like to follow his story, go to caringbridge.org and type in ryanraffel.  (one word).  This may help people realize more research needs and more attention needs to be brought to this cancer!  No 5 yr old should have to battle cancer twice.  Had there been enough research maybe we wouldn't be standing in left field praying a hoping that he can be put back in remission and then cured.  Please read his story and SHARE IT so more light can be brought to his cancer!!!

Yes, Ma'am - Legally, only those 18 and older can volunteer for this event. However - may I interest you and your family in another volunteer event that weekend? The 24th Annual Potomac River Watershed Cleanup is Sunday, April 22, 2012, from 8 am to Noon along the shorelines of Belvoir - Accotink Bay and Dogue Creek. The event is rain or shine and gloves and bags are provided. Volunteers will meet at the Environmental Education Center in Tompkins Basin. Adults, children, families, organizations, scout and community groups are encouraged to participate. To volunteer or to get more information, call Kevin Walter at (703) 805-3969. Thank you for thinking about making Belvoir even better! ~ms.

Tamara - I now have new information about Belvoir's participation, along with the Mount Vernon-Lee Chamber of Commerce, in the annual Route 1 clean-up. Volunteers needed for Route 1 clean-up. Those between ages 12-17 are welcome to help and must be accompanied by a parent. Hope this can now include your family! ~ms.
unfortunately mine are younger than 12, but will look forward to seeing more info about the April 22nd event :-)

Want to make Belvoir, surrounding waters, even better? Volunteers are needed for the 24th annual Potomac River Watershed Cleanup, which is April 22 from 8 a.m. to noon along Belvoir's shorelines. Gloves and bags are provided and volunteers are asked to dress in old, weather-appropriate clothes. The event goes on rain or shine. Inclement weather before April 22 will impact the water level in the Bay and the amount of shoreline exposed at low tide. Volunteers will meet at the Environmental Education Center. Interested volunteers and people who want more info are asked to call Kevin Walter, 703-805-3969. ~ms.

I am sorry that it has been a burden on you and your family that your smoke detectors have been checked 4-5 times since January. Since the fire in December that a young man passed away and concerns of many residents throughout the villages we decided to move our door to door campaign up to make sure that all the resident who had concerns we could answer their questions. As part of the door to door we offer to check smoke and carbon monoxide detectors to ensure that they are working and are interconnected. We also check dryer vents since this is one of the leading causes of home fires due to lent build up. We also check to see if the resident has fire extinguishers and if they know how to use them. We also hand out fire safety materials and the telephone number to call the fire department and explain if you call 911 that it goes to Fairfax County and routed to Fort Belvoir which could be a delay in time. It?s not that we don?t trust you or being responsible adults. We want to make sure that you and your family is safe.  Thank you for your understanding.

Patricia, the outdoor "Giant Voice" system is intended for people who are OUTDOORS. It CAN be heard from indoors, of course, but, you shouldn't expect to be able to make out all the words of an announcement. At the same time as we activate the 'Giant Voice,' we ALSO send the info out via other methods, such as Facebook, Twitter and the E-Mail listserv (you can subscribe to the listserv at http://listserv.belvoir.army.mil/ - subscribe with as many email addresses as you like, including home AND office).

In real emergencies we use additional media like Belvoir Online at www.belvoir.army.mil; the info hotline at (703) 805-3030, and the radio announcement system at AM1610.

"Oh hey, just thought I'd let you know.. Your husband died in combat yesterday..Ya, I'm really sorry for your loss."

Who in their right mind would deface a soldiers death like this? 
That's just inhuman. That was someone's husband you know, have a little respect.

Where is the blame for unit not keeping it  under wraps and the soldiers telling there spouses?  When this war started 10 years ago that was the policy! Soldiers kept their mouth shut too! Yes spouses are partially to blame but not totally! I just feel sorry for the spouse!

@mary k. Mckinney ward- it doesnt comply. But the spouse already heard about it and was calling for the information. Should the major have just told her to wait to see if she got a knock on the door? No. He told the truth which at that point was the only right thing to do.

My heart breaks for this young wife.  Her fellow spouses ROBBED her of the dignity of a proper and formal notification.  They with their big mouths do not even realize the magnitude of what was stolen from her.  How very sad all around.

Mary after being asked directly by the spouse and her mother all protocol goes out the window.  Their was nothing left to do except confirm the truth for this spouse. It boggles my mind to think that another spouse(s) would want to be the unofficial bearer of such sad news.  Somebody needs horsewhipped.

Yes that RD Major should have deflected her questions, played "dumb" or whatever he had to do until that spouse was OFFICIALLY notified!  It's a very sad situation all around.  The blame is on many different people and EVERYONE just needs to remember OPSEC!

No way should RD major have lied to her.  That is not the military way.  Deflect it how...well Mrs. let me think on that oh maybe another 45 minutes or so until we can get someone to your house....No way.  The only saving grace is that this poor woman had her mother with her...

Here's my opinion.  1st of all, the spouse could have not had that info UNLESS the spouse that is in the military had not called & informed them of this info!  So, no, it's not exactly the spouse's fault completely.  Secondly, it noted that Mrs Born was not at the Fort.  So, you need to factor in travel time for the causality team to make it to the State she is visiting in.  If the spouse that texted her was not aware of this timely process & had thought she had already been notified on base, she probably sent her sympathy via text for fear that the spouse was overwhelmed with calls.  This article does not state what was in the text.  I'm going to bet this spouse was offering any help she could give, not knowing that she had not been notified.
who in their "right mind" would text a condolences to another human being?  We have not become that technologically ill mannered have we.  Tacky, classless and a shame.

a very sad story we had here. As for being confirmed on the phone (after said text message) - the Maj in charge did what he had to - he couldn't "deflect" her question or lie; in the end that would have been far worse. I hope is a lesson to people - think before you speak/text/post (EVERYONE); do not assume anyone knows anything; and give things TIME (I know that's difficult in this age of instant gratification).\

If everyone would only take a moment to think how they would want to be informed...there is a notification team for a reason, and in most cases I believe they are hand picked to do so by the soldiers themselves before deployment.

If you work or live on post, or you visit here often, you are encouraged to share this information on your walls so the word gets spread even more. There are particular issues with "lead footed" drivers along Belvoir Road and Gunston Road - something about them being 4-lane now seems to cause drivers to think they need to speed up. The speed limit on Belvoir is 30mph, and on Gunston it is 25 mph.

Both Gunston and Belvoir have HOMES along the way, and there are also pedestrian crosswalks. All of us - parents, kids, pedestrians, AND drivers - share equally in the responsibility for safety on and next to the roads.

I am thankful for the patrol cars out in Gerber Village at bus time. I've seen many speeders and even some that that do not stop for the bus.  If they watch 21st St. they would catch even more speeders!

Please don't forget 9th st! Our homes are extremlly close to the roads and we have the WTU building directly across from us. Also as a friendly reminder, please be aware of the crosswalk on 9th in front of the WTU.
Lame ppl! U all probably speed and ur trying to be all goody good. Be real. Most ppl speed and dont even realize til they get pulled over.

It's hard to not pick up some speed after you finally turn off of a road that was backed up for over 20 mins b/c of this never ending construction! Or you over slept b/c it keeps you up all the time and is right in front of your house for over a yr now! Not saying it's ok to speed, but sometimes, it happens and they catch you on a bad day! I'm sure everyone of you saying "tsk tsk" on here has had "one of those days!"

My family lost a sweet baby girl due to a speeder. I was also t-boned w/ my children in the car due to a speeder. I am very diligent on watching my speed. It's not that hard to watch & obey the speed limit, its not there as a suggestion, it's the LAW! So for anyone who sucks my exhaust as I travel 25mph down Gunston, hopefully one day you will be issued a ticket & you will wake up & realize that getting where ever your headed, early or on time isn't worth speeding or that fine. Where I'm from police issue warnings/tickets for drivers who follow too closely, I think this needs to be priority here too. If you do'nt like the fact that some ppl drive the posted speed limit, go around us! And for the jerks who honk at us for driving the limit, your day will come! How about the immature drivers who wave as they pass us by, while only using select fingers! I hope you find yourself in a ditch someday as a speeder runs you off the run. I'm tired of being nice to these ignorant drivers here on Belvoir. I'm from the south were the word respect goes a long way. So jump off your high horse, lower your stuck up nose a little & look at your speedometer more often, if you fill u may drown by doing so then learn how to use cruise control! Thanks to the MP's for doing a job well done!

I am a contractor that works on base. I am always concerned about my speed and watch it very closely. The fact of the matter is, I am a visitor and I will do everything in my power to respect your community because that's what it is, a community. Just as I would expect people not speed in my neighborhood in Arlington, so should you demand the same. For the people that have left comments here that, "everyone speeds" and "stop being goody goody" this is not the Audubon! It is a military base with children, pet dogs, families. I'd rather be a "goody goody" than take the chance that I won't be able to stop in time because I'm running a little late.

Great idea!  As a bicycle commuter, I hope new bike lanes would accompany this initiative.  12th Street and Gorgas need bike lanes for safe access to retail, schools, and facilities.  Bike racks (both traditional and bike-share stations) outside of more post buildings would help with parking.

If the membership does not exceed $25 per year, or if it were to be compatible with Capital Bikeshare (either interoperable or directly operated), I'd be for it. Otherwise, it will crash and burn. Considering Capital Bikeshare is increasingly likely to expand as far north as Howard County, MD and already slated to expand to Alexandria, memberships would have more value... Daniel, one big hope is that if the bikeshare program can be effective, fewer people will drive their own cars in, and use other means to commute to and from work. ~dnc

Fort Belvoir

 As of 10 p.m. 22 Jan 2012, Fort Belvoir IOC & leadership continue to monitor the weather and will announce any impact to Belvoir duty status and operations as may be appropriate. For now the Garrison is operating under OPEN conditions with employees expected to report for work at their usual duty time. A final weather decision for the Garrison's operating status for Monday, 23 Jan, is to be made by 4 a.m. Monday morning after evaluation of road conditions and status of area schools. The decision will be reported here, on the installation's Facebook and Twitter sites, and on the info hotline at (703) 805-3030.

It's also important to note that decisons are routinely made in the early morning hours, rather than the night before in order to more accurately react to the situation rather than imperfect forecasts.

I believe one of the only ways to ensure this type of thing does not happen is for those pages turn their safety to "post only" this would keep some of it down to a minimum. I disagree. Although I think its sickening that someone would post something as extreme as that knowing it wasnt true... a lot of times posting things on a site like this is the way to get info out very quickly even when higher ups dont know about it yet. Take the recent events of a soldier posing as an MP. It was posted on the villages FB page. It then was transferred over to the wive page. Turns out the guy had already been to someones elses house. The info got our quickly so that people were able to know that a threat was there at that moment.If someone wouldnt have posted it in the first place and there was an immediate danger it could have saved someone from being hurt, killed, etc... Villages didnt let anyone know about it till later that night after they said everything was false. Thankfully the Fort Belvoir site jumped on it quickly to get the correct information that there was something going on out there. I do agree though with Joseph that we as adults need to make sure we are verifying our facts or at least posting along with it that we arnt sure if its true or not. We just want people to be safe.
This without a doubt outweighs the bad. Last night, I saw about 3 friends post rest in peace joe paterno. I went to about 4 different sites to verify it was incorrect. It's not that hard.

It's NOT that hard, Joe. Still, it can be scary how quickly people will not only accept hook-line-and-sinker what they pick up online somewhere, but will begin instantly to spread it as fact JUST because it was online somewhere. In a close-in community like a military post, we need to make extra effort to confirm things, and NOT post anything about it until absolutely sure. Otherwise, what so often happens is that the work needed to kill a rumor and calm the frayed nerves it caused becomes a major task, and takes away from dealing with real issues and concerns. ~dnc

Accumulations could include snow and sleet from a coating, up to one inch; and, freezing rain from a trace up to a tenth of an inch. A wintry precipitation will cause slippery traveling conditions late tonight through Saturday morning. Ice will accumulate on trees and power lines. Please drive careful.
As always, updates will be provided as appropriate here and on the info hotline at (703) 805-3030.

On Sunday morning, cold air will filter into our area from the northeast, undercutting the remaining moisture. This situation has the potential to cause another rain and sleet event or less intense freezing rain event in the Fort Belvoir area during the morning hours.  However, little or no accumulation is expected.
Please remember to check this Facebook page as well as the Belvoir Info Hotline at (703) 805-3030 for info on the weather's impact on Fort Belvoir services and facilities.

Please remember Fort Belvoir is a military community where uniformed and civilian members of the nation's military and their families live and work. Security is a byword. We must keep that in mind as we ask questions or launch discussions here on this completely public forum.

If I may make a suggestion... in the bullet list at the beginning (i.e. Am I being helpful, or detracting from the conversation, would I behave this way offline, etc), I would add:  

? could the wrong person use my post in a malicious manner?  

Or something to that effect - in other words, could the wrong person do damage to our security (at whatever level) based on the content of the FB post.

Good point, Leslie. Fact is, we all SHOULD have such concerns, not just with our individual comments, but, also with how a string of comments can and will be construed, used, and abused. That's as true on the open pages like this one, as it is on "closed group" pages. (Fact is, as any member of a "closed group" who has ever cut-n-pasted knows, there is no such thing as a "closed group," anyway.) ~dnc

I would encorage the author of the bullet points to ask him/herself:  Am I being paternalistic or moralistic in my wording of these points, is it my job to teach or reprimand adults concerning matters of decorum and language (which may convey my own reginal and cultural biase), what am I assuming of the people I am speaking to as I write these points, what am I actually trying to get across as I write these. Your points, while in some form of course make sence and are important, however, many are just ridiculous in their wording and some have no place in a "social network" setting.  If you came to my house and spoke to me like that, my family would invite you to leave.  Do you really think you are building the community in the way you chose your words?  Rhetorical question of course.

I'd just like to repeat a comment I wrote elsewhere on this page, to follow up on Don's excellent comments:  

Speaking as a (retired) software engineer whose last project involved testing security issues... it really doesn't matter if a page is closed or not, or if a person believes all of the privacy settings on their page will protect them from the rest of the real world. They're easily "hackable"; who knows if the administrator really checks each and every request to join a page; and who knows if someone's family member is up to no good and snooping around their computer. Who knows if it's a troll - foreign or otherwise - trying to figure out how to get in and figure out where all the security (software, installation, whatever) loopholes are (remember the ban on thumb drives?). Don has it exactly right. It's unfortunate we have to be so careful, but that is the world we live in nowadays...

Thank you, Joanna. Fact is that DOD ID is required at all gates to Fort Belvoir except Tulley. Visitors who wish to enter Fort Belvoir who do not have DOD ID must use Tulley Gate during regular hours from  5 a.m. to 9 p.m., seven days a week. After hours, 9 p.m. to 5 a.m., they must use Pence. Visiting drivers must provide a valid state driver's license, and all other occupants of the vehicle must provide valid photo ID. All visitors at all times are subject to search, of course, and the Mobilisa security system is used to scan ID. ~dnc

Hello, I am posting the following on behalf of Mr. Kevin Walter (mentioned above) for clarification: "The $5.00 fee is for volunteers over the age of 18.  These fees fund the program and help to cover the costs of generating materials for Compilers, producing an annual Christmas Bird Count (CBC) summary issue, and maintaining the CBC website and database.  Each registered volunteer is then sent the CBC summary issue which reports all of the results across North America and is broken down into regions and sectors.  The data collected by observers over the past century allow researchers, conservation biologists, and interested individuals to study the long-term health and status of bird populations across North America. In the 1980?s CBC data were used to document the decline of wintering populations of the American Black Duck, after which conservation measures were put into effect to reduce hunting pressure on this species."

Continued: "The CBC is a long-standing program of the National Audubon Society, with over 100 years of citizen science involvement. It is an early-winter bird census, where thousands of volunteers across the US, Canada and many countries in the Western Hemisphere, go out over a 24 hour period to count birds.  The first CBC was done on Christmas Day of 1900 as an alternative activity to an event called the ?side hunt? where people chose sides, then went out and shot as many birds as they could. The group that came in with the largest number of dead birds won the event. Frank Chapman, a famed ornithologist at the American Museum of Natural History and the editor of Bird-Lore (which became the publication of the National Association of Audubon Societies when that organization formed in 1905) recognized that declining bird populations could not withstand wanton over-hunting, and proposed to count birds on Christmas Day rather than shoot them."

Continued: "The CBC is a great way to bring in the New Year and everyone is urged to participate.  This is also a great opportunity for students and groups in need of community service projects.  Anyone interested in volunteering can contact Kevin Walter, Ft. Belvoir Natural Resource Specialist, at 703-805-3969."

This is why I will not be working in Northern Virginia when I get out of the Army. It is just too crowded and BRAC just crammed even more people in. It also seems contrary to military doctrine to have so many agencies in one place. When will the DoD take full advantage of virtualization technology? If they really want to save money, that's where it's at.

Actually, Chris, of the 19,300 jobs moved to Fort Belvoir, including the 6,400 going to Mark Center, only about 500 are new to the region. The other jobs were already here. But, a very significant and often overlooked point is that the same BRAC legislation actually REMOVED another 14,500 DOD jobs completely away from the region to other states.

In the final analysis, BRAC has very little to do with the extent to which Northern Virginia is crowded. This region is at the seat of the federal government, and the thousands of federal and contract jobs it takes to run it. We can all better exploit virtualization technology to get traffic off the roads. ~dnc

You mean pittied?  Yes, I agree. But then again, look how they are billed in the press. . . Service members are not painted as strong men and women, still supporting their families despite what they have been through and still able to bring home a paycheck and kiss their kids at night.  They are painted as broken men (you hardly see broken women), in need of countless hours of therapy, and additional monetary, government assistance.  I respect every single onservice member.  However,  I don't think the press, their own government, the people in charge of keeping their salery comparable to inflation, and the public see them as anything other than a wet noodle in need of coddling.
Very strong quote at the end of this story...

As usual American media focuses on the negative aspects of service rather than also address the positive. What service member hasn't gained something from their service? Whether it be skills, strength, friendship or serving the nation they love. I know I certainly never have regretted my service. I fully believe we should help veterans without pity but with great respect, for one simple fact. We all raised our right hand voluntarily to serve and protect this country of our own free will.
Cheryl Lynn Babin, you might go back and read the article again. It isn't at all about what you call the "negative aspects of service."

Ah again misunderstood. I was not referring to only this article. I meant that what the public sees "most" of the time is all the negative impacts the service has on our lives. Again I am not referring to Stars and Stripes and other military supporters. How often do you see a news cast/article on how great our lives, medical care, free education, on post housing are vs someone getting killed, PTSD, jobless, homeless?

I think what we need to remember is that sometimes things happen and they are inconvenient to us.  Life isn't perfect.  Life isn't always convenient.  But it's the way we handle those inconveniences that matter.

It's not about drama.  It's about the fact that no matter what the powers that be do, there's always someone that fails to appreciate the intention, and complains about the inconvenience.

There's a purpose for these tests.  It helps promote preparedness.  It allows for the "kinks" to be worked out.  Practice makes perfect, people.  Nothing works perfectly the first time.  Our government through catastrophes like Hurricane Katrina, the Tsunami a few years back and the Haitian earthquake are learning that we are not ready for a major disaster.  I'm thankful that those with the power to do something are trying.  And yes, irritated that people want it both ways.  They don't want to be inconvenienced under any circumstances, but yet criticize the authorities when not enough is done in their opinion when help is needed.
It was a nationwide test, not a Fort Belvoir test. Coast to coast...Belvoir didn't choose to test the system.

From a person who was active duty AND a military spouse, If I can put out one suggestion/recommendation to the spouses that you can carry with you for the rest of your active duty spouse's career:                                                                  STOP WINING AND BE THANKFUL FOR WHAT YOU HAVE BECAUSE ITS NOT ABOUT YOU!!

I can't believe you are whining when they were TESTING an EMERGENCY alert system...I get that you have kids that were sleeping but you were warned that this was gonna happen so why whine about it now?  We NEED an emegency alert system for when things DO go wrong...remember Katrina?  Maybe you didn't live through that but if you did I bet you'd be wishing they had implemented something like this...now, can we just be thankful that it was indeed just a PLANNED test?
Amen, Cathy and Michelle.
It was posted on this site a number of times in the past days that the nationwide emergency test was going to happen precisely at 2PM today.  Shouldn't have been a surprise to anyone.
@ Kristen Christensen's post: Wow...really?! 'nuff said.

I am assuming that the sailors and soldiers took care of those wounded while on deployment. I would gear my response towards healing than hurting.

Kids never cease to amaze me. I've been caught off guard by their "have you ever shot/killed anyone?" question numerous times w/o being on any subject that would pertained to that. They aren't na?ve. I found that explaining that the military does so much more that shooting is a good start. I relayed my experiences in non-combative roles to them. Steer them away from the more morbid topics w/o losing sight of the fact that they see service members as super heroes who defend the good guys.
Frankly

As a teacher and parent, and also a military spouse-my opinion is to keep it simple. They are amazed to even have you at their school, and they consider themselves lucky (and they are)! Keep it age-appropriate without divulging too much info. If they ask about shooting, tell them your experience without being graphic.Remember, YOU are a role model!
And YOU represent the military!
Honestly!

This has been going on for several weeks now, not just this week.  It is difficult to access other gates if you are coming down Mt Vernon Hwy.  Thru traffic cannot get past the gate because of the backup and you have to go through neighborhoods to get over to Rt 1.

car-pooling, public transport, cycling and walking are unfortuately not  options for myself, or many others I imagine. Honestly the only 2 options I see at this point would be to widen Walker gate so 2 cars can drive through at a time -(versus have 2 lanes merging into one). and/or secondly, having a traffic light to allow all involved a fair chance to turn.  As far as utilizing other gates, this would require many of us to back track or go a completely different direction, therefore; really don't feel that is an option either.

and my best guess is that it will not ease up on its own, especially come Nov. 5th when all gates will be open to DOD card holders (which I will say should help out Tulley/Rte 1  substaintially, but will begin to see more back ups @ other gates...)

Pence gate isn't too far if you take Surveyor Road through George Washington village, make a right at Belvoir Road, and then you're at the gate. There is a light at this gate so it should allow for traffic to pull through. And this is not even 2 miles out of the way from Walker gate. I have quick success going this way even though I live in the Village right next to Walker gate.

It wasn't so bad when there wasn't a solid white line running through the two lanes! We were taking turns. Now that the line is there the cars are not able to take turns, thus the cars coming from Route 1 go straight to the gate and right in front!!
FYI all, all gates have always been open to DOD card holders with decals on their windshield. The only thing about that changing on Nov 5 is the decal will no longer be required.

In regards to the fuel efficient spots, the hospital is taking the initiative to leave a smaller carbon foot print. Amy, we believe we will end up "all digital" one day, but, not yet. The contractor actually sells advertising to support the printing and distribution, and it is actually the  advertisers who rely on the PRINTED copy and on it being circulated to the homes, barracks, offices and other "private" areas of the installation. That access is part of what the contractor is able to sell to get the revenue he needs to do what we ask, to wit: publish the post newspaper. Another consideration is that the nature of a WEEKLY publication is such that there is just not a substantial enough advertising base to support going all digital. We continue to do what we can to inprove our online presence (that's part of what the redesigned website is all about), and, hopefully, our online presence will become attractive enough to advertisers that maybe we CAN start cutting back on the printed copies.

Then please explain why the Army moved thousands of employees away from metro and put them where they are forced to drive.

We long ago passed the point of discussion of why Congress legislated the moves. DOD was given the BRAC mission and carried it out. Fort Belvoir, the Army, the County, VDOT and others have worked very hard to provide means for people to get to work without feeling "forced to drive." Fairfax Connector's "Eagle Express" from Franconia-Springfield Metro, for example, makes it possible for ANYONE who ever commuted via Metro to their previous location (Crytal City, Pentagon, etc.) to continue using Metro. The government will even pay a subsidy of up to $230 (see http://bit.ly/nZwsHc) to offset costs.

So the more relevant question now is, why do so many of us seem to automatically feel, "forced to drive?" Regardless of what the problem is or how it originated, don't we all share in helping solve it?

My husband metros to work before the Eagle Express makes it's first stop, so he is forced to drive.  And the gov't subsidy can no longer be used to pay for Metro parking--that's $5 a day that comes out of our pocket if he chooses to park.  Luckily, he doesn't mind the free parking at the mall & the 15min walk to the Metro.

The bus enters Belvoir through Telegraph Gate and stops at the Fort Belvoir Community Hospital; John Kingman Road; Jackson Loop; and 12th Street and Gorgas Road near the commissary. The fuel-efficient bus fits 39 seated and 36 standing, for a total of 75 passengers. The "Eagle Express" provides a viable, efficient commuting option to the installation, and gives people living on Belvoir a commuting option to the Metro.
Information on Belvoir?s commuting options is available at http://www.belvoir.army.mil/rideshare/. Information about Fairfax?s County?s bus service is available at http://www.fairfaxconnector.com.
If you just moved to Belvoir from a Metro-friendly site (Crystal City, Pentagon), Eagle Express lets you keep riding the rails to work!

Think of it in reverse, too: you can catch the Eagle Express FROM Belvoir to go to the Franconio-Springfield Metro Station, and ride the rails throughout the entire Metro system - go to Maryland, visit the museums in D.C., go take a Pentagon tour. Anywhere Metro goes, you can go from Fort Belvoir, thanks to the Eagle Express.

Motorists are encouraged to make alternate travel arrangements to avoid the area around the Pentagon.  As conditions change it is possible these road closures will be broadened.  Those traveling through this area should expect significant delays for the majority of the day and are strongly encouraged to avoid the area.

Washington Boulevard southbound from Memorial Bridge

395 Northbound HOV ? no access to Washington Boulevard from N/B 395   

395 Northbound HOV ? access to Eads Street from northbound HOV, only southbound HOV exit will be closed (northbound must exit to Army Navy Drive)

Route 110 northbound will be closed from Route. All access to Route 110 will be blocked south of Memorial Drive

Hayley, I contacted the pharmacy. They let us know that within a few weeks, the new system the pharmacy will use to fill prescriptions should be up and running. Currently, the system is undergoing the final steps to make it operational. Q-flow will help to prioritize the patients and their prescriptions for quicker action and allow us to track their individual wait times better.  We're aware of the frustration with long wait times and our staff is working diligently to deliver each prescription as quickly and safely as possible. Thank you for your patience. ~ Fort Belvoir Community Hospital Public Affairs

Christine, the size and scope of this storm is significant, and its potential to drop significant, flooding rains, coupled with a storm surge that could inundate areas served by the Chesapeake, is very real. Please keep an eye on local media recommendations, as well as Belvoir and local emergency management guidance.

In the tropical cyclone preparedness game, "Nothing's happened historically" isn't the best way to plan for what might happen for any given storm. Admittedly, the northward turn this morning, and slightly more eastward track would appear to make chances of significant problems in the DC Metro area somewhat less, but the National Hurricane Center has increased the level of warning for the coast and Bay to that of a Hurricane Warning. 

This storm is significant enough to warrant watching. No, I'm not in NoVa. Yes, I do study tropical cyclones.

make sure you have enough medicines for anyone who needs them. the biggest problem I can see is the power outage likelihood.  so batteries, food that doesn't need refrigeration (and for those of us who don't eat junk food, we'll have to adjust our diet to include more prepackaged food) , radio, in  my case finding ways to keep the cell charged so my deployed spouse can contact me.  Knowing how long the power was out in some areas after the snow storms a few years ago, that's just being sensible. Don't panic, but don't plan on "normal" for a few days.
We have food, lanterns, flashlights, propane, full tanks of gas, bottled water, weather radio, survival bag is always packed and stays  in the car. And the video camera... Come on Irene!!=)

One more thing: in the event the "Giant Voice" OUTDOOR notification system is used for storm advisories, and YOU are INDOORS, do NOT worry that you can't make out what it is saying. Giant Voice is for people who are OUTDOORS (in the back yard, at the playground, taking a walk, whatever). Use the Giant Voice as your cue to check the Website, Facebook Page, E-Mail or other sources to find out what the notice is about.

I was at home here on Fort Belvoir, The kids and I were playing games. My first reaction was to grab my youngest and cover his head. I honestly thought my worst fear since living in this area had came true and we were under attack....I thought something hit my house or very close by, My whole house was swaying back and forth, Something I never thought was possible....  Very scary!! It was the first and hopefully the last for us!!

My 3 yr old son had just fallen to sleep for nap on the couch downstairs. I told my daughter that I was going to take him upstairs to his room so we could relax and watch a movie.  As I got upstairs and started to walk down the hall to his room, the house started shaking and I saw the walls moving right in front of my eyes.  I honestly thought I had gotten dizzy carrying my son up the stairs, but then my daughter started screaming.  I immediately took my son back down stairs and everything stopped.  I asked my daughter what was wrong and she said "the house was shaking!"  I thought someone had crashed into the house or something.  I ran outside and all the neighbors were standing outside.  Finally one neighbor, Liz Tracy- Porter, came home and told it was in fact a quake.  Wow!!!!!!   The weirdest, scariest, but at the same time awesome experience!

At home sittin on the front porch i had just put my 7 wk old to sleep i was scared to death i didn't know what was goin on i saw the houses shakein now im scared bc im not sure my house in dough creek is safe for me and my family

I was on third floor of the hospital, my 3 week old was at home with my mother in law. It was terrifying for a new mom. Especially because no one in the hospital seem to know if we should evacuate or not.
Tweeting from space? That is probably the coolest thing I've ever heard of.

They confirmed it is NOT leaning, but, there ARE cracks. Park Service has closed it indefinitely while they research the damage and decide way ahead for repair. Meanwhile, the other monuments, including the new Martin Luther King Memorial, ARE open.

I was sitting in my classroom waiting for my English class to start at NOVA at the Annandale campus.  We had no idea what was going on because we thought it was just construction. Our power went out and all our desks were shaking and the lights were swaying back and forth. The campus police came in the building and turned on all the fire alarms and told everyone to evacuate the buildings.
I was on the couch talking to my hubby.  My kids were all out in the backyard playing.  I took off to get them all and by the time they got in, it stopped.

Sitting in my office in the old AMC building on Hall Road, which is really just a bunch of stacked up trailers. When the ground began to shake, there was a horrible creeking sound and it felt like the building would fall on top of us. I was frozen in place and thought that it was a bomb or something that had gone off. It was really scary and then we evacuated.
Getting a pedicure - I thought the 'massage' chair was going out of control until I looked up & saw all the walls & decor shaking around me!
I was sitting in my sister's backyard in upstate NY and felt it up here....hope my pictures didn't fall off the wall back home.
I was sitting on my patio enjoying the weather, I jumped up and got my kids to the front yard.
I was at work with a customer and I just about freaked out. That was something I never felt before I didn't know if I should walk out the door or stay

I had just sat on the couch and pulled up info on Hurricane Irene, then my couch wiggled and I asked my husband what he was doing! Then it got a bit more violent and he bolted down the stairs and met me on the porch! We have never experienced anything like this and it scared to pee out of me!

I was in my kitchen loading the dishwasher after laying my son down for his nap. I thought a helicopter was about to crash into our house. I ran upstairs because my son started screaming and crying. That's when I realized it was not a helicopter but an earthquake. I had pictures on the floor and a few of them broke.

Didn't feel strong enough on my feet after chemo on Thursday to drive today so was telecommuting from my bed with my dogs for company - thought one of my trees had fallen and hit the house. (Glad I didn't need to try to get home in the afternoon traffic!)
Someone I know was at Logan getting a tooth worked on.  That can't be fun.
Sitting at a stop sign wondering what was wrong with my car and why it was shaking.  <3

I had just sat down with my lap top, after checking one of my son's assignments he'd been working on.  I was looking at a forcast map for Hurrican Irene, when it started. It took me a couple milliseconds to realize it wasn't a low flying helicopter. As I jumped up to get in the doorway, my older two kids ran in, confused. The scariest part was that during the 'quake, my youngest was out of the house with his therapist and I couldn't get ahold of them due to no phone service.

I was in a high rise in Old Town, Alexandria. I knew right away it was an earthquake (I am from CA) but ran to the window just to make sure something didn't hit our building. I saw other people in the office building across the street scrambling and just as I saw them the intensity increased. Immediately got under my desk and yelled for others to do the same. Looks like more earthquake preparedness is now needed for east coasters!

I was sitting on the floor of our new home in vernondale ,talking about The Wizard Of OZ pic my hubby just bought me, when the whole house shook, then ran outside and screamed for my kids to come inside, I guess my brain fell out LOL
Standing in the mirror and frame section of World Market.  Grabbed my son from the cart and ran out of the store.
I was standing out at pence gate scanning ids. No where to go so I just laughed and stood there.
Working diligently at my cubicle in the Oaks basement

Sitting on the floor in the dining room and entryway of my house in Fairfax Village helping my daughters unpack luggage... They were telling me about their trip to World Youth Day in Spain when the floor suddenly felt like Jell-O beneath us. We all stopped talking and stared at each other and just sort of whispered "Earthquake?!" in disbelief. As the walls really starting shaking and rolling, my 4-yo screamed and came running from the kitchen, while I got up and out from under the chandelier that was swinging madly to and fro.
Hanging out at a friends house in river village when the floor started to shake and the walls begun to move as we ran for the door way as pictures fell. last a good 25seconds crazy stuff!

SHARP Training @ Wallace Theater. Thought a Very low-flying plane was going over. Everyone was looking at each other wondering if others were feeling the shaking. Wonder if we'll have to redo that training. lol
At work sitting in my desk and on the phone. I hung up after I told the person I was on the phone with that I had to go as politely as I possibly could and left the building.
In North Carolina at my desk.  Scary thing was no cell service to call my buddy at the DCVA.

I was at home, and since we live along 9th St. wherein road construction is currently on the works, my kids and I thought at first that the rumble was due to the big trucks working outside. As I look above, our ceiling fan started to swing as well as our walls. That was a shocked to all of us and I guess "de javu" for me from the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake in San Francisco.

Driving through old town and wondering if my car's power steering finally broke.  Then I thought, well, maybe there are ruts in the road... and then - wait, is there a strong wind pushing on the car?  Nope, no wind.  So why are the stoplights swinging like they're in a hurricane? And people pouring out of the buildings?  Ah, earthquake.  I hope.  I admit I had a slight flash of a thought wondering if a bomb went off somewhere.

@Stephanie: Initial plans called for a 2013 completion date for both the Commissary and X (well, it'll be an X once they raze the PX), with construction of the remainder of the Community Support Center (the remainder being the mixed-use bits) slated for construction in 2014. Construction of the PX was stated as starting in 2011 with a likely 2012 opening of the X.  See http://www.belvoir.army.mil/wtu/Draft_Environmental_Assessment.pdf for a few clues.

@April: Wal-Mart is cheaper, but the Exchange price matches up to a $10 difference (per item) at your word; most of the price variances are less than that, and for most large purchases there are mail in rebates (though often unadvertised in-store, strangely).

...Also, they price match without dollar limitation against any local store (within 50 mi) with proof of price (can be an ad, receipt, or other documentation of price; plus, they offer a 14-day price guarantee, so if you pay more and find a better price later, you can return with your receipt and proof and get a refund for the difference.
The price-match program makes the PX at least as beneficial to shoppers as whatever the MOST beneficial store off-post is.

Mike, some might disagree - there is a cost to any business of keeping watch on the competition, and we all know what happens when a business incurs costs - they are passed onto the consumer. Don't see how this is really an issue of the "computerized info age." Really just seems likes its enough for the PX to be sure word is out on the policy of matching lower prices, and that the customers - the ones who will benefit from that - should be the ones to show proof of the competitor's lower price. (Agree that so many stores do put their stuff online, so ads and such can be printed out, of course - but, again, just seems like that's on the customer to do.) [dnc]

Keep in mind that about half of prices found beating those at AAFES stores are loss leaders. If the PX matched all those automatically, it wouldn't generate enough revenue to keep the shelves stocked, not to mention keep the lights on or pay its employees. And yes, AAFES pays for its own utilities (through reimbursing the host installation), except for MCSS facilities (those are deemed activities of the services operated on their behalf by AAFES).

Benjamin, gas on post IS nearly always a couple cents - sometimes even a nickel or better - CHEAPER than off post in Fairfax County. AAFES considers gas prices in the county in which a post is located, then sets it a few cents lower. Gas in Prince William isn't a factor in setting prices at Belvoir Exchange stations.

BUT, because the price of gas in Prince William County is nearly always cheaper than in Fairfax, gas prices at the station at Quantico MCB can be expected to always be about the best around.

Lack of attention to OPSEC rules is a problem all over the military when social networks are involved. Even without them, information is released based on the level of importance determined by a soldier or spouse instead of taking into account the way that information could harm an operation. Social networks simply make it easier to release sensitive unclassified information.

Soldiers and spouses should, at all times, remember that keeping information like troop movements, operation details and personnel status under wraps is tantamount to actively protecting the lives of all the soldiers deployed. Given that, letting information out on a whim is similar to handing the enemy information that could be used directly or indirectly against our servicemembers overseas.

Think before you speak. The military should not change its policies.

Drink plenty of fluids (non-alcoholic), even if you're not thirsty. Wear light-weight, loose-fitting clothing. Stay cool indoors. Schedule outdoor activities carefully and wear sunscreen. I got here in 08 and disliked it from the jump. We came from Fort Stewart and had never lived in housing. Got housing here, Left post housing in 09, exactly a year after signing my lease.  Likes it more now that I live 45 minutes away, but glad to be leaving.  The people are cold. I felt like I was in a morgue or doctors office when going through the Commissary as no one talks to you, not even in response to a hello. I actually smiled when a child would break the silence lol. I agree with Jess about the gates, and other things mentioned.  Housing on main post isn't set up for neighborly interactions, I felt very, very isolated.  Traffic was horrendous.  Woodlawn was run down, and where I lived was falling apart-from what I have seen of new housing there, it looks way better now, and I'm glad you turned my old street into a community center/pool area and that the road goes all around. Nice.

Oh and black mold is ignored on this post in housing. I have several soldiers who have brought in pictures and all housing did was cover it back up...disgusting. I think housing needs to be upgraded others condemned and the people taken care of better...It is not everyone just some here and there. I know I was offered mold infested housing as a cancer patient and that could have killed me very unhealthy so we moved off post because they wouldn't let my husband and I move into newer housing I am an E5 and he is and E4 with no dependents but still a sick person in a moldy house doesn't make sense.

my friend had lived in river village with a sewage main burst and they moved her to woodlawn due to it but she had to get doctors statements, information about it online and had to threaten them with writing a letter to the post commander before they would move her. My house did not have black mold or anything it was just old and run down. Maintenance lived at my house.  One thing I hated was I should have looked at the stove and fridge, whoever lived there before should not have passed inspection. I had housing bring me new ones. They were disgusting.

There is so much road construction at really weird times in front of housing. Sometimes they start working on the toad in the middle of the night and we always have to move from our master bedroom to our guest bedroom and sleep in there.

The fact that there are no line units on Fort Belvoir makes it different for me. I am used to places like Fort Bragg and Fort Sill. It changes the entire dynamic of the post. Also more civilian employees than I've ever seen before

The fact that it has nothing to for the teenagers to do , everything is closed by 8 bk doesnt open until 8 when soldiers have to be to work by 6-7, the gates close at 9, it doesnt seem like the rules are beingienforced, the movies are never open , the 4th of july nothing  for kids to do , at  campbell , it was so much to do we really didnt  have to lleave the base...i can go on and on....

Wow... Okay well where to starts. housing is amazing! Growing up we didn't have anything like this on army posts. MWR has a whole mess load of activities, the facilities that are being updated blow my mind. Starbucks, spas, subways etc. If we had live din woodlawn with the parks, pools, etc when I was a kid I would have thought my dad moved us to Disney Land. The spouses c
Clubs, FB pages etc make getting information as easy as breathing....

The new hospital, well that speaks for itself, a state of the art WTU facility, unparalleled regional support from USOs and other organizations, like OOIAL who provided an entire weekend for our family last month...baseball tickets hotel the works.... neighbors are great here in Woodlawn. We wave to each other, know each others kids, generally look out for each other. It's such a community. It has it's issues, such as th shares, construction etc, but with BRAC we knew to expect that for a little while. In a calendar year we've come so far and by this time next year its going tonbe tough to even think. About leaving lol.... But you know what they say " Your best duty stationed ever is the one your going to and the one you just came from" ;)
I love living at Belvoir but the gyms are complete garbage with a staff that is horribly rude and lacking in knowledge.
The hospital is great. Exspecially the super awesome nurse Meagan Stern in the pediatrics clinic.
I love living at belvoir and totally agree with Gena. I also love how our community can pull together when others need our help. Fort belvoir is improving for the better =)

The people set fort belvoir aside from all the rest! If you get the right group of people anything is possible and that is shown daily. The more we work together, assist each other and bond... the more creative we get in our actions, activities and thinking!

We lived in Woodlawn Village and black mold was a problem, so much so that my 6 year old was constantly sick. I was glad to move out of there. Because of BRAC, there really needs to be more gates open and the commissary, PX and gyms need upgrading.  Yes, there is the over-priced, bitter coffee chain (Starbucks) and a spa, but there are too few amenities on the post.

WE MISS THE COMMISSARY! We just PCS'd to Ft. Drum and miss the Belvoir PX and commissary very much! Also the people...loved having neighbors of all branches...not to mention that I don't speak Army so am struggling very much here ROFL! I DID take AFTB, but never had to use it at Belvoir hehehe! I love BOTH posts equally, but really do miss the commissary and px! Definitely miss the ammenities (Starbucs! Our nearest one is 12 miles away) AND having a school right on post! My kiddos will be busseed 20 miles away....I miss being across the street!
Oh! And this FB page and the Housing E-mails...that instant information ROCKED!

So much to do for families. It is a beautiful Post. Very warm and welcoming Village Communities. I also love that it is a very mixed Service Post, we have neighbors from literally every branch of Service.

black mold was a problem for us too- no ventilation systems in the bathroom....they painted over the mold, you could still see it under the paint...in woodlawn...but other than that its an ok post tp live at...
The sense of community.

I love the hospital and I've only been to the px there twice in 3 years. Since I live near quantico now I go to their commissary and mcx, its so much closer but I do stop by the shoppette on belvoir for gas when I have doctor appointments.  Its like any post you dislike things then you move and realize you might just take some of the things you hated and appreciate those things, lol. I do case lot sales at the commissary, but that's all now.  Probably won't see it again before I leave.

I lived in Jadwin right after it reopened and we loved it! Great community!! I am assigned to Ft Knox and my house is a third the size and desperately needs updating...there is no pride in neighborhoods, it's run down in comparison, and the commissary and PX just suck. I miss Belvoir...

I have lived on a total of 4 and husband 6 different installations. This is the second time I have lived on Belvoir. There are more civilian than soldiers it seems compared to other posts. Which in my opinion means less oportunities and community events for the families of soldiers when compared to larger posts.  More would help considering to do anything off post in the area takes a lot more money ($8 for a matinee movie unless you wait a month or more for it on post. I try to wait and see movies when at my parents 5 hours away for their $4 matinee). More traffic, traffic, traffic, traffic but we have learned at one times to travel and which routes to take. The post has an older feel to it compared to others. The access to local shopping, events, parks etc. is huge compared to others but again you are going to pay more unless you hit the outlet stores. And the commissary, i believe this statistcally true, is the most busy one anywhere.  I also feel that all boundaries of post should be more secure compared to other post, there are several gaps, but we know with all of the new construction this will not be a priority.  Housing is improving since the last time I have lived here but the new constructions seems very cramped but I have never had any problems with the housing offices as long as you take it to a higher person when getting no results. Example: for those with black mold or any mold, ICE, ICE, ICE! More people see the ICE issues and results are more likly to occur.  I do enjoy living on Belvoir, especially since BAH will not cover anything other than a very small apartment unless you want an hour commute, and would say it is my #2 favorite post so far. #1 being Fort Polk, I know crazy, but I have my reasons, lol.

As per our DFMWR (acting), Ms. Mills,As of today we can confirm that 3 funded and designed tennis courts will be
built in the area close to the skate park. They will be asphalt and have
lights and fencing. The project has been awarded and the contractor is ready
to start work once the site is ready. Unfortunately the site includes
underground power lines which must be relocated prior to the start of
construction. This work will be done by Dominion Power in the near future.
We anticipate the construction to take approximately 6 weeks if all goes
well and then the courts will cure for 30 days. 

Work is also ongoing to get the 2 additional new courts constructed on north
post. These two are funded and contracted, we are awaiting the necessary
work to get the sites ready for construction.

As updates become available we will pass them on to you - we are indeed
anxious to resume this very popular activity and provide tennis courts for
all ages on Fort Belvoir.

I believe safety is a community effort. Defensive and cautious driving is a MUST, especially in residential areas. Teaching and reminding children of safety is also a community effort. Again, this is only my opinion. I do not expect everyone to share it nor do I intend to push my beliefs on others. As a parent and resident I often remind both kids and drivers in my neighborhood to be careful. It's OK to remind a child to "look both ways" when you see a little one about to dart without checking.  It's OK to yell "SLOW DOWN" to a speeding motorist who pays no mind to postings OR to the kids waiting to cross the street. I would much rather be "one of those" people with an eagle eye who isn't afraid to speak up than a citizen filling out a witness report.

Rebecka, I would send a positive email or resume/cover letter to the contact info provided, talking about what you would bring to the job.  Leave out the "what you can't do

s until the interview.  That is a good way to get a face to face and sway them into liking you, then hiring you.  Leave out the childcare/ public school issue. Recommend you 'rename' your idea of how to implement the User Agreement.  ROE as you mention is not accurate.  ROE definition from Joint Publication 1-02, DoD Dictionary of Military and Associated Terms, (1994):  Directives issued by competent military authority which delineate the circumstances and limitations under which United States forces will initiate and/or continue combat engagement with other forces encountered

Thanks, Dave! Precisely because of that definition, "Rules of Engagement" has actually come to be a fairly common term used to refer to all manner of "engagement." We're thinking the DOD dictionary will catch up when they update the 1994, pre-"engage social media" edition. [dnc]

We asked The Villages at Belvoir for their comment on this thread about use of the Woodlawn Village Pool. Here's what they said: "With all new things, there will be kinks to work out. The Villages at Belvoir takes pride in the service and product we are able to provide our residents. We understand that there are some concerns with regards to the new pool at Woodlawn. The Villages at Belvoir would like to assure the residents that all lifeguards on duty are over 18 and that they are all trained in accordance with VA lifeguard and safety regulations. The guards are equipped with a telephone and in an instance where there is an altercation or someone present that is not carrying identification, etc. they will, can, and have contacted the military police. The lifeguards have also been instructed to ask anyone who is not obeying the rules and regulations to vacate the property.  It is our goal to allow all of our residents at The Villages at Belvoir a safe and fun environment to cool off this summer. If you have any further questions/concerns, please do not hesitate to contact the Woodlawn Village Management Office at (703) 781-0567. [dnc]

Michelle, it may be worth investing in a weather radio, rather than depending on the "giant voice" system meant to be heard by those outside.  Weather radios actually aren't that much money (about 30-45 bucks), and most have the option of battery operation.  They're a must in the midwest, we got ours when we lived in Kansas.  They'll wake the dead if you set the volume loud enough, no worries then!  :)

I grew up in the north end of Tornado Alley (Minnesota).  I agree with Andrea.  I would definitely invest in a weather radio.  It's loud enough to get zombies dancing, and even with my hearing aids out, I can hear it (it's right next to the bed).   Tornado sirens are a good thing, but like Michelle said, many people are inside with windows closed/ a/c running/tv on, etc and may not hear them.  I would never live without a weather radio.

Hopefully this will be better than Dewitt Hospital!! And hopefully it will offer patience services that Dewitt does not and keep patience from having to travel to other locations for health care.

Marcus, the nature of the "old" Walter Reed Health Care System was that it was by design set up to serve patients regionally. Problem was, it was designed more around the facilities in the region (DeWitt, WRAMC, Malcolm Grov) than around the beneficiaries in the region. That's why those of us who use DeWitt ( and its clinics in the 'burbs) often found ourselves referred to WRAMC or somewhere for treatment not available at DeWitt. The complete transformation of all that with the new hospital at DeWitt and all the other work on military medical care in the region turns all that around. To begon with, the new system is very much focused FIRST on the region's beneficiaries, then on development of facilities to serve them.

Won't be able to see it open - but during the 5 years that we were stationed in the VA/DC area until mid August of last year - we have watched the process from the beginning since we lived right across from it on Troth Way -  looks like it will be a updated and beautiful job well done. i was in 6th grade class...
I was in 6th grade, just got back to my school after getting braces. We were all taken into the auditorium to watch it on the tv
I was in 10th grade and home sick with my mom. she woke me up to watch it.
I was in Ohio, on vacation from my job @ the Pentagon...
I was walking on Gunter Air Force Base in Montgomery, Alabama with my friend Melissa who was pregnant with twins at the time..
we were stationed in ft carson, hubby called me from work to tell me to turn the tv on...just in time to watch the second plane go in live...was glued to the tv and radio all day and the next day
I was drinking coffee and watching Good Morning America. My kids were playing. It was less than a month from my 24th Birthday.

It was my sophmore year of college, and we spent the day waiting for my roomate's dad to call as he flew from Dallas to New York that morning. . .with all the caos, he wasn't able to call until the afternoon, but he called !!
I was cussing my moms doctors office
we were stationed in Germany
I was in 10th grade in my physics class when the reports started coming in...

in NYC. it was terrifying seeing all the people walking in the streets. Some covered in debris, some hysterical in tears. I had my toddler W/ me and was able to get on bus to go home. It took hours. All subways were closed, bridges & tunnels. The air was thick and full of sadness & worry. Screams were heard, people were all trying to contact loved ones but all lines were down. NYC had an eery lonesome feeling for days afterward. I'll never forget it.
I was in 10th grade in math class, watching it on the news!
Senior yr.- in government !!!

stationed at Fort Stewart Georgia heading out to work at the airlines.  I called our boss they hadn't heard. It was a long several days with the no fly directive.  Amazing that people didn't care that no one was flying they wanted to fly anyway.
I was in 8th grade English class!

I was teaching in Kansas, block 1 adv alg. Another teacher came in and asked if I'd heard the news. I thought it was just some gossip he wanted to share but it was bigger! Next block was my plan period and I spent it in the library glued to the tv. Five months pregnant with baby #2 wondering what kind of world he was going to know.
In my basement in Nashville, TN doing school. I was 8 when it happened. My dad called my mom from work and told her to turn the T.V. on. One day I will never forget.

My husband and I originally met at the Pentagon on 9/11....he was a first responder with the US Army (Old Guard stationed at Fort Myer) and I was working as a first responder with a federal law enforcement agency....the Old Guard soldiers were in the Pentagon crash site for days....wading through jet fuel, chemicals, etc to recover victims....just in their BDU's btw.  They are true heroes who are often forgotten during this time.....
I was stationed at Fort Huachuca, AZ...I reenlisted Sep 19 2001

I was in Hanau Germany just got back to my room from a Class A inspection when we had a mandatory formation and then were put on 24 hours of gueard duty. The German ppl would come to out gates crying and laying wreaths and lighting candle it was touching
I was at work. I didn't realized the full extent of what happened until I got home that night.

Teaching a class in Indianapolis, as all of the students' beepers and cellphones went off to call people back to their offices to secure the facilities [nearly all students being 1st responders in their home communities]
I was in the 6th grade but by the time I got to school and heard about it, it had happened 3 hours earlier because I was on the west coast
In the AF Command Post in the Pentagon. By far the worst day of my life and one that I will never forget.

Fort Belvoir has been at FP Condition "ALPHA" for more than a year. The means basically being alert for increased general threat of possible terrorist activity against personnel and facilities, the nature and extent of which are unpredictable. Some measures from higher FPCONs may be added to "Alpha," such as has been the case here - the 100% check of photo IDs of all occupants of a vehicle is a "Bravo" measure. "Alpha" measures can be maintained indefinitely.
So do my kids need their ID"s?

Today Fort Belvoir and ALL U.S. installations have been moved to FP Condition "Bravo." That is a precaution in view of today's events, and means there is increased or more predictable threat of terrorist activity.
Hollie, nothing has changed for IDs. Those who need IDs under FP Condition Alpah need them under Bravo.

How does it work?
Is this instead of just making text posts?

If you have a scanner in your iPhone, Android, Blckberry or other smartphone, you can scan this code to go to the website or file it is linked to. You can find a variety of QR Reader apps wherever you download apps for your phone. One popular reader can be found at http://reader.kaywa.com/

Once you have the app in your phone and launch it, hold it up to a QR code. The reader will "grab" it and take you automatically to the website or file that it is linked to. You can also create your own QR codes at sites like http://qrcode.kaywa.com/

Holly, for the moment, anyway, it seems like this gets its biggest bang when printed somewhere ... in a newspaper, magazine, on a poster, or a tabletop ad in a restaurant, something like that. One idea we've bounced around here is, like, when we put stories in the Eagle, and we don't have enough space to get ALL the info in that we would like to. We could have the "main" story in the paper, but then put a QR code with it that takes the reader to additional information online. Clubs could use it to offer specials of some sort ... "Scan this code for a two-for-one dinner coupon," or some such. There's probably no end to the possibilities, really ... [dnc]

So what about those of us who have large pickup trucks that hardly even fit in our garages by themselves, let alone with a second vehicle?  And then if both are parked in the garage, there is absolutely no room for anything else (not to mention the maneuvering it takes to park both in there...  definitely not practical to do every single day).  What are we supposed to do with outdoor gear?  We hunt, fish, bike, etc, and need a place to keep our gear, and have no storage shed or other appropriate area (and there is no way we are renting a storage unit for our things when we have a garage).  Perhaps if Belvoir wanted people to use garages, Pinnacle should have made them of a practical size to park two real vehicles, not two tiny economy cars.

I for one am glad to hear this, in river village people are constantly parking on the no parking side of the street making it nearly impossible to pass, they seem to think that just because there is a 3 foot section if curb not painted yellow  they can park there
Guess they never thought of emergency response when the planned such narrow roads?  Or was the plan to always paint the curbs and limit parking?  But I agree with speeding enforcement...

I fit a truck, car, two motorcycles and two bicycles in my garage, using any combination of two vehicles each day. I still have plenty of room left over for all my excess belongings that don't fit or belong in closets. It is important to note that garages are not supposed to be used primarily for storing things other than vehicles. I believe a generous overflow parking lot should be established somewhere in each village for over-sized and excess vehicles to aid in clearing the streets. Woodlawn has one for each cul-de-sac and they work well.

Federal law caps the interest rate at 36% APR for Service Members, and Virginia lenders may charge upfront origination fees up to 20%.  Because of this, we recommend Soldiers use EXTREME caution and only apply for these loans if  better options aren't available (such as temporary assistance from extended family or AER Loans).

PLEASE don't fall in to that trap!  Use AER or other loans first.  Have pot lucks with neighbors or eat lots of Ramen, carpool to save on gas, host game night to save on entertainment expenses!!!  We'll get thru this eventually, but it's so hard to dig yourself back out of the hold that those stupid payday lenders suck you in to!!!!  Stay strong!

The navy/ marines made their version of AER loans readily available to Navy personal.  All you need is your military ID and sign for it.  That's it.  Why can't the department of the army come out with this policy during the government shutdown.  Anyone who has gotten or tried to get an AER loan knows that it is a PITA to get it approved.  I hope they are flexible because they are going to get a lot of calls and people that are in need.
