Hi Mr tony From Walter Reed
Women Army Corps?
My GMa was in the WAC in Savannah and also at Fort Gordon, GA.  She worked in the armory.  I will forever miss her :)

WAC were the first female soliders in the military but was disbanded in 1978 and those serving at that time were put in the regular armyi n the specialty field they were trained in and working for. Im guessing this picture was taken in the late 1950's like 58 or 59
sorry it stands for Women's Army Auxiliary Corps and each branch of the service had a similar one such as the Navy WAVES, the SPARS of the Coast Guard and the (civil) Women Airforce Service Pilots.

Women's Army Corps is right! Photo was taken Sept. 29, 1944. WACs took jobs as secretaries, clerks, typsists, technicians and translators. Some helped prepare detailed maps and reports before troops would move. Specially qualified WACs made plans for reconstruction of bombed railroads, highways and towns. The women served as phone operators in theatre set up in stables or cellars working 8 to 10 hour shifts 7 days a week. (information from the Belvoir Castle Newspaper). (jnl)

Fatal accident closes Route 1 in Mount Vernon
By Washington Post Editors
4:55 p.m. Update: One person has died and numerous other people are injured in a multiple vehicle car crash on Route 1 in the Mount Vernon area, Fairfax County police said Monday. The highway is closed in both directions at the scene of the crash.

Fairfax Officer Bud Walker said the crash occurred at 4:02 p.m. in the northbound lanes of Route 1, just prior to the intersection with the Fairfax County Parkway. He had no details on how the crash happened or how many vehicles were involved. He said the gender and age of the person who was killed was not available.

Northbound lanes of Route 1 are completely blocked, Walker said. Southbound traffic is being diverted on to the Fairfax County Parkway. Ambulances were still making their way to the scene at 4:45 p.m.

? Tom Jackman 

Orginal post: An accident at Route 1 and the Fairfax County Parkway may tie up traffic in the area, which is already congested with rush-hour traffic, for several hours, according to emergency officials. 

Authorities say police and rescue crews are on the scene, and drivers should seek alternate routes. 

However, the lack of major surface roads in the area is going to make that difficult, especially if you?re already on the road. 

Share a suggested alternative by posting a comment below. 

By Washington Post Editors  |  04:33 PM ET, 03/21/2011

To encourage employers (to include our GS system) to consider alternative work schedules, part time positions and job sharing. There is a whole pool of talent that is getting missed out on due to a lack of these kind of jobs.

We PULLED the discussion because it reached a point where a number of things were being said that are either partially or totally incorrect or misleading. Being passionate and committed to an issue is one thing, but, firing off missives without really knowing something for sure is dangerous. It doesn't help with public understanding as much as it adds to frustration and confusion.

The Fort Belvoir Facebook page is completely wide open. It is intended to be, because we invite our followers to raise legitimate issues and concerns that can be resolved in open, frank discussion. It is especially fulfilling to watch the various threads here and see that all of us are responsive to each other, and genuinely helpful.

But, we have to guard against the temptation this "new media" presents to instantly pound out our comments on things that maybe we really aren't completely sure of. We have to take that occasional deep breath, count to 10, and maybe make a couple phone calls to ask some questions first.
It's very important to be sure of things before we put something up here that just really doesn't inform as much as it MISinforms - however well-intentioned we might be as we make our posts.

The Belvoir page now has more than 3,000 followers, and - we're sure - a GREAT many more folks who just drop by to read the wall, but, haven't clicked our "Like" button yet. That's why we have the "Rules of Engagement" (click the 'ROE' tab in the menu under the Belvoir logo). Please keep them in mind as you post here.
@ Fort Belvoir, Thank you taking interest.

Susan, Katrina - please go back and read through what we've said here. The earlier discussion has been referred to those who can provide us insight to the FACTS that we can then share, not just here, but in the Belvoir Eagle.
But, again, it isn't helpful to be passing along 2d and 3d hand info about what someone said someone else said, ESPECIALLY when the issues are as serious as those you've raised here.

According to the CDC Flu seasons are unpredictable in a number of ways. Although epidemics of flu happen every year, the timing, severity, and length of the epidemic depends on many factors, including what influenza viruses are spreading and whether they match the viruses in the vaccine. Reports have come in that there is an increase in flu activity, and DeWitt has flu shots available.

Statistically, more harm will come to personnel (Soldiers and civilians alike) from obesity and smoking. Obesity kills the equivalent number of Americans as 2 fully loaded 747's crashing, EVERY DAY. Even more deaths are attributed to tobacco use. If you really want to look out for our health and welfare, aggressively promote tobacco cessation, stop subsidizing it through cigarette sales at AAFES, and make it easy for people to exercise and walk on post by designing and enforcing bike lanes and bike right-of-ways, better sidewalks, kid parks, etc, and give people healthy eating choices on post. Michelle, work will begin in a few months to cut a new gate into Fremont Field directly across from Pence. The road going in there will curve south to link up with Constitution Avenue at the old Leiber Gate. Robyn, good points! Couple clarifications - and we encourage everyone to PLEASE share this info throughout your organization:
1) The Garrison's decision always applies to the Garrison workforce. The Tenant Commanders/Directors DO have authority to make their own weather calls. Some choose to wait for Garrison; others choose to go with OPM; still others do make their own calls independent of OPM or Garrison.
2) The Garrison does NOT go by the OPM decision - indeed, it is OPM's policy that their decisions do NOT apply to federal agencies outside the beltway. The OPM decision can be useful - but isn't critical - along with other considerations in helping the Garrison decide a course of action.
3) Bottom line is the individual employee certainly has a role to play in their own decision. The employee who just heard on the radio, for example, that his kid's school is dismissing early and will be headed home, probably needs to talk to his supervisor and take a few hours leave to depart post regardless of what his organization or the Garrison might do.

Jennifer, that's probably not really completely fair, honestly. After all, a GREAT deal of information was put out for benefit of ALL drivers through the entire period explaining road conditions (they were AMBER most of the time), and advising extreme caution. Even in the best of weather the last several months, the construction has been a necessary and understandable reality around which we've all had to drive responsibily. It's actually a credit to us all that, all through Wednesday night and Thursday morning, there were no accidents.

I left Fort Belvoir at 330PM and didn't get to my home in Western Fairfax County until 210AM.  The conditions deteriorated at a quick rate and I must admit it had me wondering why Fort Belvoir decides not to follow the OPM guidelines.  I would think that OPM has much more experience dealing with weather and Federal Government Employees than Fort Belvoir does.  Civilians don't live on Fort Belvoir.  We live many miles away.  My brother works downtown DC and he arrived home before the snow started as he was allowed to leave quite a bit earlier than I was.  I also like how the policy stated that if you left earlier than the early dismissal time, you would be charged for the entire rest of your work day.

Jim, it is actually OPM's policy that their decisions "apply to employees in all Executive agencies with offices located inside the 'Washington Capital Beltway' (the highway that circles the Nation?s capital)." See page 2 of the OPM dismissal manual at http://www.opm.gov/oca/compmemo/dismissal.pdf.

Leave is a matter of Civilian Personnel policy. The OPM manual, on page 8, says this about charging leave when an employee leaves before Early Dismissal is invoked: "An employee who leaves work before an early departure policy is announced, or before his or her early departure time, should be charged annual leave or leave without pay beginning at the time the employee left work and for the remainder of his or her scheduled workday ..." A similar question can come up when the installation status is "2-Hour Delayed Arrival OR Unscheduled Leave." 2-Hour Delay gives an employee up to 2 hours extra to get to work and not be charged leave. If an employee chooses to take Unscheduled Leave for the day instead, that would be 8 hours.

Thanks for the reference to manuals and policies.  It still doesn't make up for the fact that many folks were stranded on the roads and it could have been avoided or minimized if Fort Belvoir had followed OPM's lead.  Stranding of motorists on their way home due to no fault of their own in cold weather should not be overlooked as a safety issue.  Fort Belvoir did not do all they could have done to minimize the number of cars on the road during this storm.  If you sat in traffic as long as I did that afternoon/evening/early morning then you would understand what I am really talking about here.

I personally do not like this article. The main content is quotes taken from this very page, and many of those quotes can be taken out of context as several were pulled from larger and detailed comments/statements. The article's author should have contacted individuals personally who are pro and against ( I realize that most who are against the bugles primarily have issue with the volume and not the bugle calls themselves) and gotten comments that were not fuled by the negative tone of the conversations that instigated the quotes that were used. There should have been information included explaining the purpose of the bugle calls and why they should be expected on a military installation.  
The quote from Lt. Solivan come across in a way that make it seem that the command at Ft. Belvoir is uncaring to the concerns of its residents, when they have been attempting to correct the volume and have even scaled back drastically the number of speakers used. There is also the impression that we as a community are not capable of behaving in a civilized manner and can not discuss this issue without tossing hateful, hurtful, and just down and out nasty commens at each other.
This article was a good attempt to shed light on a current issue, but it seems a bit rushed. This is just my opinion.
I am glad they are still being played, I like the bugle calls.

Monica, I definitately agree with most of your points. This article was not well-written at all. And it certainly makes every effort to portray Belvoir - and all of us - in the worst possible light.  Here's a suggestion: Instead of arguing amongst ourselves about the bugles, let's join forces and make sure that there is no opportunity to write articles like this.  The fact is, hateful things are being said to no avail.
How embarrassing that it came to this.....

The article didn't portray anything--it took THE EXACT WORDS some of the complainers/whiners had posted on this PUBLIC site.  You can't blame the author for that, only those that were quoted in the article can be blamed.  I believe somewhere during these debates it was pointed out by Fort Belvoir that this was a public page and we weren't giving the right impression of the base.  And, BTW, I live in Colyer and heard the bugle just ONCE--the first time they broadcasted Taps.  I wish I lived closer to an intercom.

Here's the thing, it wasn't just the "complainers/whiners" that were quoted as having said nasty things.  It wasn't only one side of the debate quoted, the point of the article was that both sides were in an uproar. Both sides were quoted and neither was more "right" than the other.  I suppose we shall never learn, I was only indicating that peace might be good. However, since my pleas for peace are obviously only adding fuel to the fire, I'll retreat.  I wish peace to you all, regardless of your "side".

Seems to me like the easiest way to make ALL parties happy is to rotate the speakers.  Play the calls from each speaker, one at a time, rotated through the week. 

 I respect those of you that like the bugles, I have no problem with them. In fact, I enjoy them when I hear them.  However, I only enjoy them if they don't wake my child.  It's not so easy to move off post with the BAH so low and the cost of living so high.  No one has beomoaned military tradition, but if it becomes tradition to impact our children's health negatively, the Army will lose many more members.  Already there are those of you complaining about the members of the Army that treat this as a "job" and not a lifestyle.  Well, seems to me that if you continue to abuse your members and family, this is the reaction you should expect.  

If the bugles are played on a rotating basis on one speaker, any given neighborhood would hear them once every twelve days.  Surely we can understand meeting tradition and caring for families, simultaneously.  Perhaps, being woken once every 12 days would be liveable while still ensuring that others can enjoy their well-loved military traditions?

Wow. Never assume you're with adults. Thank you for turning off the speakers.
What were we talking about again?  Oh, that's right, BUGLE CALLS.
Hey all you pro bugle supporters out there, you can complain all you want about us, but we got our way.  :)

All the bugle lovers need to understand that Ft Belvoir sits in the larger community of Mt Vernon.  When you have the greater community hearing the bugles off post 2-3 miles away, they have to address it.  If I can hear it inside my home over near Mt Vernon Estate I can sympathize with those of you that live within a stones throw.  There are other ways of honoring military tradition.  My husband served for 30 years so we are patriotic as well.

Personally, I'm disappointed.  I've never known the military to "give in" so easily. Heck!  When I needed something "for the health of my children and myself" I have NEVER had anyone jump so quickly to help me.  But that's a different discussion.

With that said, I do like the idea of rotating the speakers.  I'm not going to pretend to understand the work involved in that, so if that's not possible, then I'd understand.  But I think it might be a very good idea.  

But I have to agree with all of those who are saying this is unfortunate.  In the past, I've done things to try to accomodate things out of my control.  I've always slept with a radio on, for example, for this exact reason.  When I was younger, when my dad was in the military, I slept with a radio to drown out the helicoptors, cannons, etc.  Not too loud, but loud enough that the "sudden" noises outside didnt' seem as loud and I was less likely to wake up.  My children now do the same thing and with the exception of my autistic child, sleep through everything!  Even my autistic child banging on the window at 3 am (which is so loud I can and have heard it a block down the road--my apologies to my neighbors).  

I'm not saying that some people haven't tried adjusting their ways to live with the bugles, but to those who just expect everyone around you to accomodate you, that's a shame.

Please understand we're talking about speakers not originally designed for anything BUT word announcements intended to be LOUD. The announcements would convey EMERGENCY info to people OUTDOORS. Seemed only logical to look at whether they could not ALSO be used for the bugle calls.

We were advised that chips could be provided for some of the speakers to play music, AND at a volume LOWER than that used for the voice messages. We identified six of the total 18 speakers to put the chips in so that they could be used for BOTH bugle calls AND the voice messages.

We were ready to launch last week. As fate would have it, the calls were programmed to all 18 speakers - that would be 12 equipped ONLY with the voice volume, and another 6 equipped with the chips for the music. Some of us wonder whether maybe the ACCIDENTAL playing of the music on all 18 speakers rattled the windows in the space shuttle!

Services available through the tax center include: Free, IRS-certified electronic preparation and filing of state and federal tax returns for military members, retirees and their dependents. Specifically, representatives from the Staff Judge Advocate office will prepare the following types of returns: IRS Forms 1040, 1040A, and 1040EZ; all state returns; Combat Exclusion Pay returns; Two or Less Rental Incomes ( Schedule E); Schedule C- EZ; LLC and Sole Proprietorship Relating to Child Care; Past year returns; and 1099C - Cancellation of Debt. When people go to the tax center for preparation, they should bring the following: ? Military ID, ? Social Security cards or other proof of Social Security number for yourself and family members ? Voided check for direct deposit information ? W-2s from each employer ? 1099-INT, 1099-DIV, 1099-B from banks, credit unions, stocks, bonds, and mutual funds ? Records for IRA contributions ? 1098-E for student loan interest paid ? 1098 for mortgage interest and private mortgage insurance ? Any other 1099 or 1098 forms you get ? Records for taxes paid: real estate, personal property, and sales tax on new vehicles ? Records for charitable contributions ? Records for non-reimbursed moving expenses ? Records for all other income you have received ? Copy of last year's return ? All receipts, organized and totaled.

I love the fact that military posts have workout facilities available at no cost to soldiers and their families. However, I'd like to see them incorporate a childcare facility so that families can benefit even more. Otherwise paying for an actual gym membership at a local facility that has a childcare area is the only other option for those who desperately need to workout but have to take their kids. But to some, in these days and times, that can be monetarily inconvienient. Opening a childcare facility and charge a flat rate or passes for a certain number of visits for childcare could benefit the gym or even BOSS or other programs. I'd love to be able to help put together and organize such a program if it can be considered.

AAA Recycling and Trash will collect holiday trees throughout The Villages at Belvoir on Wednesday, Jan. 5, and again on Wednesday, Jan. 12. Only trees will be removed on these dates.  Your trash and recyclables will still be collected on their regular days.

To have your tree removed, please be certain to remove all decorations, to include the stand, lights, ornaments, tinsel, and garland. Please be sure there is no metal attached to the tree and please do not place the tree in a bag. Place the tree by the curb in sections, each section no more than six (6) feet in length.
If you decide to dispose of your tree after these special pick-up dates, please just leave the tree for pick-up along with your other trash. Contact your community manager if you have any questions.

After last year's feet of snow, today should have been a cake walk for Fort Belvoir. I have to say that I was disappointed in Belvoir's reaction today. As always, we appreciate the posting. We followed the stream while waiting in the hour and twenty six minute Belvoir traffic jam.

It was very stunning how quickly the roads on post backed up, wasn't it? With agencies dismissing staffs early after holiday party luncheons, and both Fairfax and Prince William schools dismissed early, prompting parents across post to need to leave, all roads to the post's gates were jammed tight by just about noon time.

That meant the nearly 20 plow trucks (11 ISS crews and a number of additional brought in in contingency contracts) were not able to get on the roads to plow and treat them. The leadership, operations, MP, and public works teams are aware and looking at ways similar situations can be avoided.

As to last year's storms, a big difference is that both of last year's storms hit AFTER duty hours, so it was a relatively smoother operation for the crews to get on the roads, treat them, and then keep them treated.

A Lesson That Should Be Taught In All Schools

Back in September of 2005, on the first day of school, Martha Cothren, a social studies school teacher at Robinson High School in Little Rock, did something not to be forgotten.

On the first day of school, with the permission of the school superintendent, the principal and the building supervisor, she removed all of the desks out of her classroom. When the 1st period kids entered the room they discovered that there were no desks.

Looking around, confused, they asked, ?<span>Ms. Cothren , where?re our desks??

She replied, ?You can?t have a desk until you tell me what you have done to earn the right to sit at a desk.?

They thought, ?Well, maybe it?s our grades.?

?No,? she said.

?Maybe it?s our behavior.? She told them, ?No, it?s not even your behavior?

And so, they came and went, the first period, second period, third period. Still no desks in the classroom.

By early afternoon television news crews had started gathering in Ms. Cothren?s classroom to report about this crazy teacher who had taken all the desks out of her room.

The final period of the day came and as the puzzled students found seats on the floor of the deskless classroom.Martha Cothren said, ?Throughout the day no one has been able to tell me just what he/she has done to earn the right to sit at the desks that are ordinarily found in this classroom. Now I am going to tell you.?

At this point, Martha Cothren went over to the door of her classroom and opened it.

Twenty-seven (27) U.S. Veterans, all in uniforms, walked into that classroom, each one carrying a school desk.

The Vets began placing the school desks in rows, and then they would walk over and stand alongside the wall.  By the time the last soldier had set the final desk in place those kids started to understand, perhaps for the first time in their lives, just how the right to sit at those desks had been earned.

Martha said, ?You didn?t earn the right to sit at these desks. These heroes did it for you. They placed the desks here for you. Now, it?s up to you to sit in them. It is your responsibility to learn, to be good students, to be good citizens. They paid the price so that you could have the freedom to get an education. Don?t ever forget it.?

For those of us unfamiliar with the housing areas @ Belvoir - Does "The Villages at Belvoir" refer to all of the housing areas within the base or to a specific area?
It is sad but true.  Soldiers employed by the US Govt is a stable, and certain job, but the paychecks do not justify being a 24/7 on call employee.

It doesn't surprise me one bit.  I also think it's far more complicated an issue.  There may be a lot of common reasons why younger folks get themselves into trouble, especially with the "help" of predatory lenders.  But, some of those folks would be that way, no matter where they are employed.

In addition, I think that moving families from base to base causes financial problem amongst the lower ranks. There is not enough space here to address that.  But, we have had to leave countless belongings behind, that wouldn't fit in the truck.  The moves damage and weaken our furniture.  I have seen the piles of belongings left behind by other families.  Those things need to be replaced. 

We could also get into the shaky concept of buying a house to live in on active duty.  It works out okay for some.  But, even though we bought under what we could afford, and not at the peak of the market, we sold at a loss at the last transfer. We were lucky to sell at all.

thinking back to our financially hard times, i dont have to think back far, i'm living the example: PCS!!!! with 4 children a dog and a cat is ALWAYS our financial downfall no matter how well we try to prepare ourselfs or how  much financial help the army does give us...for one our household income shrinks down to half because i had to quit my job about a month before the move, then we had to find temporary lodging for 3 weeks (a lot of people even longer) till we got housing..we couldnt go in on post lodging and 1 hotelroom for 6 people with  dog and cat is just not working so we needed 2 rooms in a cheap roach motel because they took pets free...gave up and rented a vacation trailer in texas for 3 weeks..big chunk of our budget, then the car broke down (breaks finally gave in to the virginia salt-rust and gave the texan mechanic quite some to ponder about how THAT happened) so another unexpected expense but not uncommon when you drive on post for 5 years and then throw your vehicle on a 1400 mile marathon...and finally at the new duty station, it took 3 month to transfer my job that i did for over 4 years at belvoir, i had to start from 0 with taking the same classes again, even tho all posts go by the same army regulations, but each post can use their own rules..so we left ft belvoir in june, and had to live on less than half of our family income since and i am finally allowed to work but it' will take weeks to get my first good paycheck and we are done with our savings and once again paycheck to days before paycheck broke...love the army life!!!

oh and lets not forget the extra trouble and stress when moving during the school year, the supplies most school require are only stocked during school supply time in august and hard to get, if at all, at any other time, added expenses at the new duty station, like having to rent storage space when the new house is a lot smaller than the old one, having to leave tons of food and cleaning supplies with neighbors because the movers wont take it and having to replace those at the new place..the list goes on and on ;)

Yvonne addressed what I meant.  We have to move ourselves each time, because moving weights are based on rank.  It wasn't until 11.5 years into our marriage that we finally moved up to 3 whole bedrooms for our weight limit.  The Coast Guard yeoman promotions bottleneck at the E-5 level and it can take many years to move up.  Sometimes they haven't promoted at all.  But, in that time we did have 2 children and I came into the marriage with one.  So, we are a family of five, breaking our backs to move ourselves, leaving things behind as we go.  When we moved out of our home, 30% of what we owned stayed behind and not by choice.  It broke my heart to leave the kids toys, my son's basketball hoop, a train table, patio furniture, desks, an oak and marble hall tree, and more, all left behind.  Plus, things get destroyed, no matter how careful you pack.  

Then you arrive to find that you have to get an electric dryer, because yours is gas.  You need a freezer, because housing only gives you an apartment size refrigerator unit for a 4 bedroom house and you can't even fit your normal groceries in it.  You have to buy extra storage furniture, because storage is lacking.  Furniture starts falling apart because it was never intended to be moved multiple times.  It's painful and it's very expensive.

Totally agree with everything you've said.  And, it doesn't help that each post does things a little different.  I was shocked when we moved to Belvoir and were told that, not only was the wait for housing 18 months (!!!), but that the Housing Services Office "couldn't help us" (their words), so we ended up living in a hotel for 3 weeks out of our own pocket.  It is robbery, the way the Army helps less and less each time we PCS.  Thankfully we think ahead and prepare beforehand, but I am astonished at how much more expensive each PCS move gets.  DLA is a joke.  We had to use it for the hotel - what about all the stuff we had to replace, like Yvonne said?

It doesn't help when you live in a low cost ares say Fort Riley then come to a high cost area like Fort belvoir and your on E4 pay. You stay broke most the time. You can't get help because your taking AER loans and robbing peter to paul. Most services here are higher in cost than say what most civilans pay...180$ for cable/phone/internet when comcast charges less. You don't get many options as to who your provider is...ie FIOS. 

Lets not even get into the cost at the commissary. I understand that in fort belvoir's case most the military here is officers but that doesn't help lower enlisted that is here for one reason or another and it's hurting us on a compassionate reassignment because Dewitt can't handle most of our EFMP's so we are driving to walter reed, bethesda and children's and that adds up...then add in the maintaince of vehicles with oil changes starting at almost 40$ a pop it gets pricey and then you have to juggle what's need the most and pay that while other bills suffer.

Something has to give!
thank you for letting us know!!

There will be an emergency management exercise conducted throughout the National Capital Region from Oct 13-15. Capital Shield will bring more than 80 federal & local agencies together to test the response to an event impacting DC, Va, & Md.

Residents should take note that this exercise will simulate the movement and treatment of mock victims to area hospitals. This exercise will not impact residents ability to be promptly seen at a local hospital however residence may be exposed to people dressed up to look like they have been severely injured. Residents should not be alarmed. This is a planned exercise to test the regions capability to respond to a mass casualty scenario.

Absolutely ridiculous.  Having lived in this area now for almost 7 years, and worked on Belvoir the whole time, often on the night shift I can say without a doubt that Fort Belvoir owns little of that noise.  I've often been surprised at how little noise DOES come from the airfield.  Granted, when the sun starts coming up you can hear some engines winding up and some flights start coming and going, but it is a rare thing to see or hear one in the middle of the night.  
Fairfax County's Helicopters buzz around far more often, making all kinds of racket, but it always makes me feel a bit better knowing that they are up there.
The Medstar and Coast Guard Rescue guys often traverse our airspace, and rightfully so!
And as for the gentlemans claim in that article, well, I would LOVE to see what damage the Helicopters have caused to property.

All part of living in this area & all part of being in the military. Saying "our" helicopters r a nuisance is like saying our soldiers running cadence during PT is inappropriate; this non-sense is all null & void in my mind. Bring on the "noise"!

So, does this increased effort extend to the helicopters and small aircraft that take short cuts across Fairfax Village enroute to Davidson Air Field?  I'm all for freedom and the necessary work of the military, but too many of these aircraft are too far off the flight pattern.  Some of them fly so close to my house that I can see the people in them from my backyard or bathroom window.  Besides the unbelievable noise pollution and likely structural damage that is gradually happening to these houses, it leaves one wondering how much the people in the aircraft can see of us?!
I have to agree-we live on a military base. You have to assume there will be heavy air traffic.

There is always going to be air traffic on military post, but some of these guys are flying so low I can see the underbelly of the helicopters and even sometimes the soldiers themselves pretty scarry in housing on post. Are they gonna replace windows that shatter because of them?

I am up late most nights and its not the military helicopters going over its the one for the hospitals going to and from  People need to look up and actually see what it is before assumptions are made.

About structural damage caused by the aircraft is just a sign of poor cheap construction. I lived about a half a bock at max from the runway at Pope airforce base while at Fort Bragg and they flew C-17, C-130 and any helecopter you can think of along with all the field artillery blowing junk up everyday and ALL night. No problems there. So why is it a problem here with such small and minimal air traffic.

I haven't heard of it happening here yet, but I know when I lived near andrew's afb it was horrid. The post had to replace all this cilivians windows because the jet was too low and shattered all thier windows, it made the news and they weren't the only ones. I'm usually outside I see alot of helicopters than I see commercial airlines so.
yeah afb are awful to live near they have LOTS of air traffic and very noisy ones at that. But like someone else said its the sound of freedom and what it takes to keep us safe everyday.

I would rather hear the Air noise than Tanks going off on night fire.. Talk about waking you right up!  But when you live on or near Military Installation, you will hear or feel the sounds. I for One feel safer knowing our Military is out there. I grew up around smaller airports and a smaller base, so this "noise" is soothing.

My husband was in the Pentagon.  I spent some terrified hours waiting to hear from him.  
@Jesse-I actually called my children's schools to make sure they weren't telling the kids what happened.  My children knew their dad worked in the Pentagon and I didn't want them to know what was going on.  I was very grateful that neither one of their schools filled the kids in on what was happening.  At that time I figured that our lives as a family might be changing forever and I wanted them to be clueless for as long as possible.

I was in 8th grade homeroom when my teacher's husband called to let her know what was happening. All day nothing went on during class, we just all watched the news to stay updated. It wasn't until I was in basic training did I actually see the video of the plane actually hitting the towers. I started to tear up instantly.

I was at home with my 2 little ones when my Mom in Law called and told me to turn on the news. I couldn't believe it , seeing the plane hit the tower brought me to my knees in tears and in prayer. My heart still breaks for all those lost on that day, and I still feel devistated every time I see a video of the towers falling. The firemen and policemen who rushed into those buildings are amazing to me and are Heros, dead or alive. I am grateful for what they do each day!! You are not forgotten!!

We were living in housing that was part of Selfridge ANGB, located just off the base. I was home with my 2 and 3.5 year old sons.  Their older brother was in his 4th grade classroom.  To this day I regret not going to get him, because he apparently was one of few kids left.  But, I was given the impression that it was safer to leave him there and that was what other parent were doing.  He still talks about that day.  It affected him deeply and gave him a sense of duty.  He was able to go to the 9/11 Memorial at Ground Zero, leaving his thoughts on a card they provide.  

I called back "home" to CA and talked to my grandfather who was in the Navy during WWII.  I was just sitting in stunned disbelief.  My husband, obviously, didn't come home from work that night.  We were scared living next to a base by Detroit, wondering if we could be a target.  We had evacuation plans.  
I also remember being pretty glued to the news, listening to Dan Rather.....mostly hoping for some explanation......that what I was seeing wasn't real.......

My cousin's husband has been in the Air Force.  He's now a doctor and they have twin little girls.   He wasn't at the Pentagon that day, away TDY somewhere.  But, it's my understanding that his office was in the area that was hit.
How life is to short.  To many people have already forgotten today and that is one of the saddest thing for our country.  Ithink of where I was that day and remember it all.  God Bless America.

My Father Commanding Officer of Red River Army Depot at the time, I had just graduated High School that summer. Being the teenager I was I was sleeping, till my mother came bursting through my bedroom door and told me what was going on, I got and my eyes stayed glued to the TV and the radio in my room on with the newcast. Red River Army Depot was on locked, we were not allowed leave, no one allowed in. Security Guards circle  our all day and night.. The Depot stayed on barricade for about a month or so after, it was hard to have my friends over, or to leave, being it was a tiny Depot they knew whom we were. Life forever changed that day.

I was at the beauty salon getting my hair trimmed when I heard that an airplane hit one of the towers. My first thought was that it was a small private plane and I said a prayer for the pilot's family.  As I drove home and listened to the radio I quickly learned the awful scope of the tragedy.  I arrived home and turned on the television just minutes before the first tower fell. I just stood there, all alone in my living room, trying to process what I was seeing.   I remember the crisp blue sky that day with absolutely no jet trails.  That was so eerie to me.  I still think of it when i see a cloudless blue sky.
I worked @HRC.  I remember looking out the windows seeing the Pentagon on fire.  How our lives changed that day.....we will never forget.

September 11 is not all a day of mourning to me. It?s a memory of when America as a whole country came together. Helped their neighbors donated  blood, food, anything they could think of. A time where their was no Black, White, Asian, Hispanic we were one all taken back by a single cause. All pushing forward as one complete unit. Showing our love for America and its people by flying flags sending flowers, lighting candles in memory of people we have never met. Crying for the lost of people whom we may have never liked at all. 

The attacks on September 11 2001 is what really inspired me more to join the military. I wanted to be apart of something greater.  To help protect a nation I so deeply cared about. 

I was in 10th grade when everything happen. The school I was in also had us watching the TV. I was scare about what was happening. Later finding out one of the terrorist ate at the same pizza hut my family did the night  before they set their plan into motion on the final day. I was a Jr. firefighter at the time so we were put on alert for days after. I lived on the major incoming and got going traffic for the  Jetport in Portland, Maine and for days to not hear a plane go over was what really sank home something very wrong was happening. I came from a small town the store owners son who the whole town knew had an appointment in one of the towers. He  slept through his alarm for the first time in many many years. Had he not slept through he might have died in the one of those towers.
I was in the 6th grade then was sitting in myclassroom when we got the word I remember freaking out all daybecause my grandmother lived in New york and all the phone lines were busy

This might sound dumb, but is there a description on what is "learned/taught" in a Suicide Prevention Class?  Also, it is for 1.5 hours only?

Absolutely! The objectives of the class are: 1) To understand an individual or leader?s role in reducing the stigma associated with needing or seeking behavioral health care 2) To encourage self-referrals for professional help 3) To know the risk factors of psychological distress and the warning signs that may mean a person is likely to attempt suicide 4) To understand actions that can be taken to intervene and prevent suicide 5) To understand that everyone has a responsibility to intervene when a person is in crisis 6)To understand suicide. The classes are 1.5 hours long.

My gripe on education at the moment is that I am getting PCS'd to a post where school started 3 weeks ago, but school on our current post doesn't start for 2 more weeks. I can't enroll my kids in school until my sign-in date, and couldn't get my orders changed to accomodate the start of school. So, my kids are going to miss a full month of school where we are going, and they will also get out a full month earlier than what they were used to.  Granted, THEY love it, but I am not liking it one bit.  WHY don't all posts with a population over a certain amount have DoD schools that ALL follow the same schedule and curriculum....I really feel like my kids are getting the short end of the stick because I am the one being moved around.

I happen to agree with that Heather, they should really set all schools across the country on one schedule and only adjust it when the school needs to be closed due to in climate weather or disaster type things. Personally school year round would be great but only a few select states have that option.

i agree with heather AND i wish cyss/fcc would be better regulated from post to post. as a provider, we all have to follow AR 608-10, so you would assume, pcs would be a breeze to reopen at the new duty station, but on top of AR 608-10 every post has their own rules and regulations and it seems different background checks that force us to handle the move and stress with new schools like heather PLUS having to retake the fcc class and all that..going on my month 4 of not being able to do, what i did for the last 4 years on ft belvoir and have to start like i dont hae a clue.

I completely agree with this.  We've been lucky in that our children have gone to one school so far.  But most of their friends change schools every year or every two years.  Meanwhile, valuable school time is lost.  But the curriculum is a good point as well.  When moving from one school district to another, either the child is behind or ahead of the rest of their peers because the quality of education and curriculums differ.

Route 1 was built in 1914. It was known at the time as the Virginia Post Road or the Alexandria Highway. Camp A.A. Humphreys construction began in January 1918.

Virginia experienced the most severe winter in years. There was a foot of snow on the ground every day until late February. The thaw began on Feb. 22, which turned every dirt road to a quagmire. Every day, 6,000 civilian construction workers were trucked from Alexandria to Camp Humphreys over the dirt roads. Thousands of heavy trucks, bearing construction materials for the camp, also pounded the roads.

as far as family/servicemember well being its pretty good. i wish the gym had a family room. in germany there was a play area for them in a specific room and in that room there was also cardio equipment for parents (the play area was enclosed). Number 1:  I understand there is a lot of construction going on here, but there is a big need for more sidewalks and more street lights.  I walk at nights and there are so many uneven sidewalks (if at all) that are not very well lit (if at all).  It is just an accident waiting to happen.

Number 2: What is the deal with not having a curfew for minors!!!??  It is not right for teenagers to roam around post at 3 o'clock in the morning!  This is the first military post I have been stationed at that doesn't have a curfew for kids.
Number 3:  When is the playground next to the skatepark expected to be finished?
I have to agree with Ms. McGinnity. I really wish there was a gym that had a play room.

I agree about the gym play area. Had one at Fort bragg little room with some cardio stuff in it and an enclosed play area with toys tv for kids and even had a crib in it you just had to bring your own sheets I think (did not have a child back then but i still saw it) 

Robyn if this place does not have a curfew this is the first place we have been that did NOT have one for minors. My husband reenlisted to come to this post hoping for once just kind of relax and be a family after a few long hard years at Fort Bragg, NC  of both of us being soldiers and deployments. We hate it here one of the worst post we have been to out all the ones we have ever been at together and seperate.

For Robyn and others who asked about a curfew, we checked with some folks and can offer this response: The Garrison Commander supports Fairfax County and the State of Virginia in dealing with juvenile matters. The federal judiciary has no venue for the prosecution of juvenile offenders for mischievous mischief and subsequently, Fairfax County does not have a curfew.

The failure of some parents to properly supervise their children is not indicative of all parents. If groups of children or teenagers are seen after hours, and what is considered to be normal hours for their age groups, residents are encouraged to call the Fort Belvoir Police at (703) 806-3105 and report the suspicious activity.

I said Ft. Drum because they know how to throw a deployment LOL...deploying from Belvoir was a huge disappointment...hubby went as an IA and we had no support whatsoever...no information, no programs for families...I hear that has changed in the last three years though!
Ft. Drum (the area) also had a super fun drive in theater, great weather for outdoorsy people, modern (and handicapped accessible!) library, and NO TRAFFIC LOL! PLUS, I'm from Northern Virginia! I liked getting away from "home."

Fort Bragg, NC because everyone in the unit were so close to each other and became friends because they knew they would be deployed for a year together. Here people are like whatever I got my family thats all I need. MWR was about 100% better then this one. Lots of things for families to do and going to the pool did not cost anything. Plus there was no traffic compare to here. When something was wrong with your house they at least gave you a day and a 3 hour time slot they would be there so you could plan your day around it unlike here were they just show up when they want.

Kuwait. right before Desert Storm in 1989/90 it was great ! I was only 6 at the time, but i remember there was never a dull moment. Or Alaska, Ft. Richardson. 6mos sun, 6mos darkness and the Northen Lights! Beautiful !

Okinawa, as a school aged child I made friends with the locals, grew bananas in our yard, observed lizards and chameleons in our house and around the yard...loved the warm weather and our camping trips to the beach.  There is boys & girls day there and I participated in the parade with other local children and played lots of Japanese games that I still think about today.

Fort Benning GA Because we love Columbus. It's a slower paced city. Not too big not too small and not far from ATL. Columbus is a very military friendly place and do a lot of events for miitary families both on and off post. We like the heat and hate the cold and snow. 
This would be a nice spot too if it wasn't so close to the city and all its congestion. Traffic is too much of a headache here. Makes it not a fun place to be...

I agree with Ally about the closeness it was great at Ft. Bragg, I also agree with Patty..Okinawa was insane but I think so far I loved Monterey, CA it was so beautiful we lived off Hwy 1 and seeing the ocean everyday was a breath taking view followed by everything being so close: Las Vegas, LA, San Fran...good times

Residents meet with Fort Belvoir Police at the North Post swimming pool #3 from 6 to 8 p.m. for food and giveaways. Sgt. 1st Class Sumalee Bustamante, of Belvoir?s Directorate of Emergency Services, said DES personnel will give out T-shirts and coloring books to promote the event.

Other activities include bounce tents, a dunk tank, fingerprinting tables and a K-9 demonstration. Post Commander Col. John Strycula and Post CSM Gabriel Berhane will be on hand to sign a proclamation pledging Belvoir?s commitment to encouraging neighborhood camaraderie for safer streets.
Parking is available at Woodlawn Church or across the street at the Commissary. More information is available by calling (703) 806-3783 or from http://www.belvoir.army.mil.

I am grateful for the commitment to the families.  I proud to see the Army and alll military branches working with families challenged by disabilities.
There is one problem though.  The process itself is too long and my husband is currently at Ft. Leonard Wood waiting assignment to his next duty station with our son in a residential facility in Indianapolis for children with behavioral issues, so we are currently waiting for him to get a duty station that fits our sons condition.
Now he graduated 23 June and is sitting around doing details that do not fit what he accomplished in 21R. His SSgt is trying to get his papework rolling with no avail, but it will be a couple of weeks if it will be that.  I am one of many families that is waiting those couple of weeks and my paperwork has been sent in over a month ago, due to Ft. Jackson, SC telling my husband to wait until he gets to his AIT when it states through the EFMP policy that it is to be done when it is to be done when he is processing into basic training.  I just want to see the families and ourselves get on the right track and not be told that there is 800 (via Ft. Lewis-McChord) applicants waiting and there is nothing they can do to help the process.

I love what the Army does for our EFMP families but the process is long and ppl like us have fallen thur the cracks more than once. And we are now fighting to stay put now, our daughter needs to be here but it seems we different answers from different ppl and we need more continuity of care and answer fro familes. We don't have time for the hurry up and wait game. I feel that the army needs to retrain units on the proper handling and process of paperwork. It gets upsetting trying to track it and get NO answers, you ask for help from numerous ppl and are told to go to 50 different ppl and still NO answers. 
The Army has come a long way but we still have a lot more ground to cover.

I agree.  In addition, there is a lot of EFMP scamming, and that's terrible, but it really only hurts those of us that truly need the EFMP care.  Housing is a fine example.  The attitude of disdain following an EFMP request is disheartening at best.  There are many programs put in place to help, but many units and civilian workers still need training to help families make the best choice for their soldier AND his family.

And there our many families who have adults on the EFMP, like a spouse such as myself who when you look at me on the outside...I might look prefectly fine too you but on the inside..Im not and truly do not think...I would be on the EFMP if I did not need to be unfourntaley we moved and seriously should of stayed put because it has been a nightmare for medical care for me and caused me more problems then good but we will adapt and over come and make the best of this...I just wish this current base had more EFMP actives for adults like our last duty station it was amazing all the programs they had and how...I got to interact with others who had medical problems just like me now...Im toss to the side because the focus at this new base is only for the children its ok...I have learn to deal with it for now : )

I agree, EFMP is hard to not fall through the cracks we have as a family have every and i do mean every time! NO ONE HAS THE ANSWERS and thats not the answer, i had to send my efm to my parents for him to get the proper education.

Does anyone know if the EFMP takes volunteers? I'm a FT student and I'm about to graduate and start my Master's program. I really want to get involved with the EFMP because that is where I would like to eventually have a career.

Specialized help for those with disabilities or other issues like ADD/ADHD.

also listen to the parents. I told the school every year for 4 years that my son had a reading disability. They wouldnt listen until it came time for my son to take the SOL and he couldnt read it.  So now my son is finally getting the help he needs.   IF they would follow the already in place rules, they would have found it years ago.  BY VA law, they are supposed to test every child transfering into the district.  They never tested any of my 3 when we first moved here.

I couldnt agree more Dana.  My son is currently placed an extremly restirictive environment, way over restrictive, just because they don't have the specialized education/resources and staff knowledge for this problem.
Parent Training we can use to help our Autistic kids....and better ways to network with services in the community.
make it easier to get an iep..took me years what by law was only supposed to take 60 days...and i agree with the add part...belvoir needs counselors on hand not only video conference

I'd like to see Ft Belvoir go to a DoD school system.  My kids have no issues with learning, but for as many kids who come and go around here due to PCS's and such, it would be easier for kids to pick up and move to another school that is doing the same thing at the same time.  I am thrilled with my younger daughter's 2nd grade teacher, but totally had-it-up-to-here (points to middle of forehead) with my older daughter's 3rd grade teacher.  There doesn't seem to be any uniformity in policies, expectations from one teacher to the next and such, and I have spend FAR too much time trying to hash this out with the school this year for my older daughter.

Where to begin..having (2) children with IEPs and one of which is more broken down in more detail, I would love to see more services available for special needs children. My daughter will be a freshman this year and she will be in a basic skills class but my son will be a sophomore and he has a learning processing disorder and I feel the teacher sem to forget and until I remind them, I feel the military could offer tutoring (maybe volunteer bases) for our young community at the youth center? Just thinking out loud. Lol. I feel (my thought) we need to all put our best foot forward to help not only our children but our neighbor's child to succeed in everything. School, education is our future. We all need to do our part

Where do I start?  How about schools that are welcoming to children with special challenges.  How about consistent requirements when we transfer.  Imagine my oldest son's schock when he goes from a HS that has not instituted exit exams for his grade and has a great special ed support staff to going to a school demanding 6 SOL"s and very minimal, poor quality support.  

Imagine his schock to realize that the High School is not a place for a "regular guy".  They only care about college bound kids, not guys who want to be in service.  They emphasize their "standard of excellence", but are not an excellent school.  

I hate the school district here.  HATE, HATE, HATE!.   They are too large and oh so arrogant.  It's like finding your way through a labyrinth, just to get a simple referral.  Forget about trying to go to meetings that are too far away.  

My autistic son (youngest of my 3 sons) does not have the help he needs, either.  The schools do not have rooms for high functioning autistic children.  My son has been utterly miserable to the point of extreme distress this year, because of the ridiculous SOL demands placed on him, as well as the homework that is too hard for him.  There is no place to put him. 

I am dreading sending the middle son to middle school.  We need a better place for our kids.

I could go on for a couple of hours.  There is so much wrong that it's almost hard to narrow the list.

I can feel the utter frustrations expressed by both of these ladies...just so you know, having children with special needs in any public school, not just military, is EXTREMELY challenging.  

I have a daughter, now 23, who was in special ed classes since preschool and we moved a lot also.  The fight that I had to go through at each and every school to develop an effective IEP for her amounted literally to a fight for her life.  

The happy ending I suppose is in knowing that if you keep at it - don't give up - find a productive way to work with school officials on your child's behalf then you will get through it and so will your child.  My daughter just finished her freshman year away at college and absolutely loved it.  It was a very good year for her. 

If you have any questions on developing effective IEPs or any other more general questions, you can visit my website www.paths2choice.com for more information or contact me directly, debbie@paths2choice.com.

Take care and keep it up!

I have dealt with IEP's in 3 states in 4 school districts.  CA and VA tie for the worst.  But, I will give VA the worst marks, because the district is too big and it's too hard to get ahold of the right people.  Also, because of the intense focus on the SOL"S 

I have been dealing with IEP's for 10 years and with 2 different kids.  I am not new at this.  I am frustrated because we cannot pick where the bases are.  We cannot pick the schools.  We are stuck with what is here and many people hate it. Nearly every parent I have ever spoken to on base hates this school district.  They are doing something really wrong.

My oldest son just graduated last friday.  He finally found a place for himself.  But, his first year was a horrible, depression filled mess and his grades fell.  He rallied thanks to finally finding a place for himself.  He graduated with more success than many teenagers who do not have an IEP.   He had a lot of success in JROTC, spent 2 years on the honor roll, received school related awards, had a super successful novice crew season finishing 3rd in the state, became an Eagle Scout, and much more.  I do not credit the school with this.  He did have some really good teachers (and some really bad ones). But, the school itself .....nope. 

I blame the elementary school for tormenting my autistic child with scholastic demands that he cannot meet.  We are working to change that.  But, these stupid SOL"s should not be forced on autistic children who cannot understand the material.  Apparently, the only way to get my child excused is by getting a letter from his physician.  Apparently, the school administration are powerless to do anything but agree with me.  

I have more than frustration.  My youngest son has been having nightmares and trying to avoid school 2 days a week for months.  Whose fault is that?  I have to request everything.  They offer very little or nothing.  It's like every bit of help available is a mystery.  You have to know the right buzz words or you don't get what you need.  

There is so much more.  Oh, my....there is just so much wrong.
Many college campuses have unreachable VA reps to help with the GI bill.  Seems they would want to help get your money.

Im with Dana and Amy. Better Special Education Teachers Also regular teacher should have knowledge of all learning disabilities. Im talkin about how to know better ways know a kid with ADHD and not just say pills are not working

I've never been sponsored. What does that mean?
That means that someone helps you inprocess to a new duty station.
i was supposed to get a sponsor when my husband went to korea, but he never showed up at the house. wasnt allowed to stay in housing back then without a sponsor, managed just fine by myself :)

Remember our first duty station in Louisiana - just getting there after driving from PA to find out his  sponsor was TDY - and no we hadn't received any type of notification and no one to be the POC!!

The best sponsorship we had was when we went to Baumholder, GE.  We were given a great guy who spoke German and had actually grown up in the area.  He drove us all over and showed us soo much.  He helped us find our place off post.  He even negotiated to have our dogs allowed to stay in the house.  He taught us some German and showed as alot about the culture.  Rabb was the best!!  He even helped us with our drivers test and buying a local car.  I miss that guy!!
The one I'm going to now:  US Embassy in Poland.  I've been talking with them for almost 2 years now.

Unfortunately, we've never benefited from sponsorship.  We managed to muddle through getting to and returning from Germany on our own.  The program would be of great benefit to first timers too.  This program really should be revamped and it's importance stressed to those in a position to do something about it.

I think it would be a good thing especially for new soldiers and spouses. It took us forever to get changed to Tricare Prime because we didnt have anyone to help us. The Community Manager for your village can add your email address to the list used for their "OneCall" emails. They used OneCall to put info out about the Cinco de Mayo events. You should be receiving the Eagle at your home.
